[388] Review An overview of deep eutectic solvents: Alternative for organic electrolytes, aqueous systems & ionic liquids for electrochemical energy storage Akshay Sharma a Renuka Sharma a Ramesh C. Thakur a ⁎ Lakhveer Singh b a Department of Chemistry, Himachal Pradesh University, Summer Hill, Shimla, 171005, Himachal Pradesh, India Department of Chemistry Himachal Pradesh University Summer Hill Shimla, 171005 Himachal Pradesh India Department of Chemistry, Himachal Pradesh University, Summer Hill, Shimla, 171005, Himachal Pradesh, India b Department of Chemistry, Sardar Patel University, Mandi, 175001, Himachal Pradesh, India Department of Chemistry Sardar Patel University Mandi, 175001 Himachal Pradesh India Department of Chemistry, Sardar Patel University, Mandi, 175001, Himachal Pradesh, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review explores the fundamentals and potential of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as alternatives to conventional solvents in electrochemical energy storage and analyzes the recent advancements concerning their electrochemical applications. As the demand for sustainable energy sources continues to rise, the need for efficient and reliable energy storage systems becomes crucial. In order to effectively store and distribute renewable energy, new and innovative solutions must be explored. This review examines the deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as a green, safe, and affordable solution for the electrochemical energy storage and conversion field, offering tremendous opportunities and a promising future. DESs are a class of environment-friendly solvents known for their low toxicity and unique properties, such as their good conductivity, high thermal stability, and non-flammability. This review explores the fundamentals, preparations, and various interactions that often predominate in the formation of DESs, the properties of DESs, and how DESs are better than traditional solvents involving cost-ineffective and unsafe organic electrolytes and ionic liquids as well as inefficient aqueous systems due to low energy density for electrochemical energy storage applications. Then, a particular focus is placed on the various electrochemical applications of DESs, including their role in the electrolytes in batteries/supercapacitors, electropolishing and electrodeposition of metals, synthesis of electrode materials, recycling of electrodes, and their potential for use in CO2 capture. The review concludes by exploring the challenges, research gaps, and future potential of DESs in electrochemical applications, providing a comprehensive overview, and highlighting key considerations for their design and use. Keywords Deep eutectic solvent Green solvent Hole theory Energy storage devices Aqueous electrolyte 1 Introduction Climate change and the energy crisis are some of the most serious global problems of the twenty-first century [1,2]. The burning of fossil fuels for energy has been identified as the major contributor to these problems. The increasing demand for energy from residential, commercial, and agricultural sectors, particularly in developing countries, has led to over-reliance on fossil fuels [3–5]. As a result, there is a growing consensus that a transition to sustainable energy sources is necessary to mitigate the impacts of climate change and to ensure a reliable energy supply in the future [6]. Renewable energy options like solar, wind, and hydropower are frequently considered to be viable solutions to the current energy crisis. These sources of energy are sustainable and have a much lower environmental impact compared to fossil fuels. However, the intermittent nature of these sources of energy is a major drawback [7,8]. This is where the development of next-generation energy storage devices comes in. The next-generation energy storage devices are considered one of the key innovations that have the potential to transform the energy industry and address the issue of intermittent generation [9,10]. Energy storage devices such as batteries, supercapacitors, hydrogen storage, and thermal storage systems can store energy and release it when needed [11–13]. This allows for a more consistent and reliable energy supply, even when the source of energy is not always available [14–16]. However, with the advancement in technology, researchers are exploring new methods and materials for energy storage, which will make them more efficient, economical, and safer for the environment [17,18]. Electrolytes play a significant role in these energy storage devices, for instance, redox flow batteries (RFBs) need electrolytes that are highly soluble in solvents containing redox-active materials. Therefore, electrolytes must also be specially crafted to facilitate quick and reversible charge transport across mass electrolytes and interfaces. Consequently, one of the most crucial requirements for green and sustainable energy storage devices is the use of eco-friendly solvents that have little or no impact on aquatic organisms and the environment [19]. High conductivity, low viscosity, consistent thermal and electrochemical properties, and good electrode suitability are essential for an optimal electrolyte [20,21]. Electrolytes, which facilitate the movement of charge carriers between electrodes, affect the energy density, cell voltage, rate capability, and of course safety of energy storage devices in a substantial way [22]. Organic electrolytes are widely used in high-voltage metal-ion batteries are flammable and pose safety risks [23]. Recently, alternative forms of electrolytes such as ceramic, solid polymers, and composite solid-state electrolytes have received attention as a potential solution for the next generation of energy storage devices due to their non-combustible characteristics, durability, and resistance to heat and ability to suppress the formation of dendrites [24,25]. However, these solid-state electrolytes have limited energy density and electrochemical stability. Another category of electrolytes is aqueous electrolytes which offer high ionic conductivity but are limited by their narrow electrochemical stability window [26]. During the last two decades, ionic liquids (ILs) have emerged as a potential alternative electrolyte due to their wide electrochemical stability window and ability to couple high-voltage cathode/anode pairs [27]. Nevertheless, typical ILs at standard temperatures have weak ionic conductivity, insufficient solubility of non-organic salts, and thick consistency, all of which can negatively impact energy performance [28]. In addition, these ILs can be expensive and corrosive to current collectors. As a result, researchers are exploring alternative electrolytes that are safer, eco-friendly, and offer good ionic conductivity and chemical compatibility with cell components. A novel category of liquids, known as “Deep Eutectic Solvents” (DESs), has attracted a lot of attention lately as ILs counterparts because they share many of the same traits and features as ILs, including minimal volatility, good ionic conductivity, lowflammability, and excellent chemical resistance [29,30]. The rapid growth of these can be seen from the data in Fig. 1 , where we found an exponential increase in the number of publications on the keyword “deep eutectic solvent” over the timeline from 2009 to 2023. DESs are typically described as systems comprising at least two main components, a molecule that donates a hydrogen bond (HBD) and a molecule that accepts a hydrogen bond (HBA), that may self-associate to create a new eutectic phase with a melting point (below room temperature) lower than the melting point of each component present [31,32]. Since hydrogen-bonding interaction among an anion and an HBD are even more strongly preferred than lattice energies of the pure ingredients, unlike ILs, lowering in freezing pointis used to achieve the liquid state. These fluids are thus, distinguished from conventional molten salts by the name “deep eutectic solvents” [33]. They are also referred to as “analogues of ILs,” particularly due to their capacity to serve as customizable solvents that can be engineered to possess specific characteristics akin to those of ILs. However, in comparison to conventional ILs, DESs are easy to manufacture, cheaper, and are not water-sensitive which give them additional advantages over ILs. Additionally, few toxicological characteristics of DES compounds have been identified, and early studies found that DESs are biodegradable [34]. Because of all these properties, DESs were proposed as substitute electrolytes in energy storage systems, although the field of DESs in electrochemistry is still in its infancy but is developing very quickly [35]. This can be seen from the data in Fig. 1, where we found, the number of publications on the keywords “deep eutectic solvent” AND “electrolyte” saw rapid growth over the past few years. The discovery of DESs was a significant advancement, and many sectors have benefited from their low cost and adaptable physiochemical characteristics. Along with electrolytes in energy storage applications, DESs have been employed in a variety of other electrochemical operations, including Metal Electrodeposition [36,37], Synthesis and Catalysis [38,39], Alloy Coatings, Composite Coatings, Solvents for the synthesis of Metal Nanoparticles electrodes [40], Metal Electropolishing [41–45], Gas Adsorption [46], Extraction and Treatment of metal compounds from metal oxides [47,48], and many more. Given the cost and time involved in carrying out extensive experimental measurements, customizing DESs for particular applications through their almost infinite synthetic combinations might be both a drawback and a gain. This highlights the necessity of comprehensive research on describing other types of DES and the study of the physiochemical, thermodynamic, and electrochemical properties of DES starting from the molecular level. Recently some review articles have been published on electrochemical energy storage applications of DESs like DESs in electrochemical sensing [49], DESs as electrolytes in batteries/supercapacitors [50], reline based DES as electrolyte for energy storage [51], DESs derived advanced functional materials for energy storage and environmental applications [52]. However, there are not many reports on the complete comprehensive recent advancements of DESs in Electrochemical Energy Storage Applications. Therefore, we think a particular review article concentrating on the detailed analysis of DESs including their fundamentals as well as their role as an alternative to the traditional solvents in electrochemical energy storage applicationswould be highly important for the advancement of materials science and future technologies. This review presents an overview of deep eutectic solvents, their types, preparation, and molecular interactions involved in DESs’ formation. This review also provides a detailed discussion of the properties of DESs such as electrochemical stability, density, ionic conductivity, viscosity, non-flammability, and green credentials, making them suitable for a variety of electrochemical applications. Subsequently, this review also draws a comparison between the electrochemical performance of conventional liquid electrolytes (organic, aqueous, and ILs) and DESs. It further focuses on recent scientific and experimental research about the effects that DESs have on a variety of electrochemical technologies, such as battery/supercapacitors technology, dye-sensitized solar cells, electrodeposition and electropolishing of metals, and recycling of electrode materials, as well as environmental applications, such as carbon dioxide (CO2) capture [24,53–58]. The possibility of adding water and other additives in DESs to enhance their electrochemical properties has also been discussed on the basis of hole theory. The performance analysis of various reported systems has been examined and compared, highlighting any limitations and challenges within the field. Additionally, promising areas for future research have been discussed. Through this review article, we are trying to motivate researchers to employ DESs as a potent instrument to advance the boundaries of technologies, energy, and environmental engineering. 2 Deep eutectic solvents Andrew P. Abbott and his colleagues did ground-breaking work in the identification and study of DESs. DESs were first found as a result of an investigation into ILs. They designed and synthesized liquids in 2001 by combining “quaternary ammonium salts with zinc chloride salts” [59]. In their study, a mixture of quaternary ammonium and zinc chloride compounds was blended together to create a substance with a melting point close to 25 °C. The liquid was extremely comparable to an IL because both constituents were ionic materials. After doing this, Abbott and associates investigated combinations of quaternary ammonium salts and other molecular HBDs, such as urea and carboxylic acids and a more thorough investigation revealed that these DESshad a significant number of molecular constituents [60]. When two materials are combined, DES develops and the melting point (mp) of the resulting substance is significantly lowered. For example, the melting temperature can drop by more than 200 K in DES systems that contain a quaternary ammonium salt like choline chloride (ChCl) and another HBD species like Urea (1:2 molar ratio) (commonly named as reline) [61]. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy has demonstrated that the considerable decrease in freezing point ( Δ T f ) when compared to ChCl (302 °C) or urea (133 °C) is caused by the charge delocalization occurring via hydrogen bonding between HBD (urea) molecule and halide ion (chloride ion). These solvents are intriguing since they are not only liquid at room temperature but also extremely adjustable and solubilizing. So, we can generalize the definition “DESs as the mixtures of Lewis acidand Brønsted bases that have a much lower freezing point than their individual components” [62]. Fig. 2 depicts a schematic illustration of the formation of a DES (reline). Since the initial study identifying reline, the discipline has since broadened and has recognized a large collection of potential constituents to incorporate a wide variety of known DESs can be seen in Fig. 3 . Despite the significant similarities between ILs and DESs in terms of their physical properties and practical uses, there exist fundamental distinctions between these two liquids. ILs and DESs have two fundamental distinctions, which are related to the starting materials and the processes of synthesis. In contrast to ILs, DESs are comprised of diverse HBAs and HBDs, whereas ILs are formed through the combination of organic heterocyclic cations and organic or inorganic anions. It is important to avoid combining components of DESs that can react with each other, unlike ILs. The synthesis of ILs involves multiple steps using various reagents, organic solvents and generates by-products and waste. The reaction time can be up to 48 h and the temperature ranges from 25 to 100 °C. Cation formation and anion exchange are the two main steps in synthesizing ILs, which involves protonation or quaternization of the amine and treatment of halide salt with a Lewis acid or anion metathesis. In contrast, DESs can be easily prepared through heating or grinding [63]. In recent studies, structural differences are also noted between synthesized ILs and DESs [64]. Concentric solvation shells make up the structure of ILs, while DESs the shell separation is not so neat, and strong close-range interactions are found between both choline and urea with chloride, and between urea molecules [64]. Abbott classified the DESs in accordance with the HBD and HBA used and gave a standard formula Cat+X−zY, where Cat+ mostly is an ammonium cation, but can also be a sulfonium, or phosphonium cation, X is a halide anion that functions as a Lewis base, X and Y (a Lewis acid or Brønsted base) combine to generate the complex anionic species (the quantity of Y molecules in interaction with the anion is represented by the symbol z) as shown in Fig. 4 (a). Type 1 DESs represented by MCl x ,made fromquaternary ammonium salts can be compared to the well-researched metal halide/imidazolium salt systems. Imidazolium and chloroaluminate mixtures are well-known examples, as are less widely used ILs with imidazolium salts mixed with other metal halides, such as FeCl2 and ZnCl2 [65]. Type I DESs are difficult to produce since there are not many non-hydrated metal halides with the necessary low melting temperatures; however, Type II DESs may be created by combining hydrated metal halides with ChCl. Numerous hydrated metal salts are economical and may be used in large-scale industrial operations due to their inherent resistance to oxygen and moisture. Type III DESs are of interest because they can dissolve a variety of transition metal compounds, such as oxides and chlorides [31,66]. These compounds are made of ChCl and HBDs. Most ILs that are liquid at room temperature are made of an organic cation, which is often composed of ammonium moieties. Because of their high charge density, inorganic cations typically do not create low melting point eutectics; nevertheless, prior research has demonstrated that metal halide and urea compositions can produce eutectics with melting temperatures as low as 150 °C.Additionally, it was established that a diversity of metals that are in a state of transition can be incorporated into eutectics under normal temperature conditions, and these materials are currently referred to as Type IV DESs [67]. These metal compounds typically do not break down into ions in solutions that do not contain water, however, it has been established that ZnCl2 can do so when combined with urea, acetamide, and ethylene glycol. Type V is a recently discovered class that exclusively consists of nonionic, molecular HBDs and HBAs [68,69]. It is thought that the presence of hydrogen bonding is particularly prevalent in Type V DESs as they do not have an ionic component, yet still exhibit characteristics of DES melting points [70]. Apart from this, Natural DES (NADES) formed with the addition ofnatural substances and Therapeutic DES (THEDES) are two new kinds of DES that have recently received more attention. 2.1 NADESs The term “natural deep eutectic solvents” (NADESs) refers to “the combinationof amino acids, organic acids and bases, sugars, polyalcohols, and sugar alcohols, that interact via hydrogen bonding and when mixed in particular molar ratios they liquefy” [71,72]. In 2011, researchers originally proposed the idea of NADESs, speculating on the potential presence of a third liquid medium in addition to water and lipids in living things. Since they are made from natural materials and are thought to have a true biological role in nature, natural DESs, also known as NADESs, have been offered as an alternative. NADESs are created using typical, naturally occurring substances that areoften found in food. Even though this should ensure a minimaldegree of toxicity, it must still be evaluated in the mixture of substances before usage in foods, medications, and cosmetics [73]. Through hydrogen bond testing, the toxicity of ChCl-based DESs in the presence of glucose, oxalic acid, and glycerol was investigated. According to the results of phytotoxicity studies, the NADESs had no negative effects on seed germination [74]. Investigations using NMR spectroscopy showed that there was hydrogen bonding between the components. Numerous non-water soluble biomolecules, including gluten, DNA, and starch, have greater solubilities in the new NADES than in water, according to solubilization tests [75]. It also investigated whether NADES was present in plants. NADES were further supported as a potential extraction medium for bioactive chemicals as well as stabilizing agents in subsequent research conducted in the year 2013–14.It was discovered that the hues of safflower are more steadfast in NADES derived from sugar compared to water. This is attributed to the robust formation of hydrogen bonding between NADES molecules and dissolved substances [76]. NADESs are a new class of adaptable green solvents that are affordable, secure, non-toxic, sustainable, and ecologically friendly. The numerous uses of NADESs, such as their use in extraction, enzyme-catalyzed reaction media, the disintegration of compounds that are not soluble in water, as well as utilizing it as a means of transportation for drugs and beauty products, among other purposes, will serve as a foundation for further study into their prominence as solvents that can be used more widely for industrial purposes. 2.2 THEDESs DESs provide the potential qualities required for effective drug compositions. The solvent system can be customized for use in a variety of applications, such as drug formulation, distribution, or dissolution, depending on the components used in DES manufacture [77,78]. The phrase “therapeutic deep eutectic solvents” (THEDES), which was first used in the area of pharmaceutical sciences, is described as bioactive eutectic systems made up of an active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) as a component of DES constituents. THEDES was created by combining APIs such as acetylsalicylic acid, ibuprofen, and phenylacetic acid with frequently used HBAs (menthol, ChCl). The melting points of these eutectic solvents might be above or below the surrounding temperature [79]. The potential application of these systems as better pharmaceutical formulations to address problems with drug permeability and solubility is what has sparked interest in them. The initial workon THEDES was published in 1998 by, who produced an ibuprofen and menthol combination to improve skin permeability and create a transdermal administration method [80]. In 2009, it was found that the solubilities of benzoic acid, itraconazole, and griseofulvin in ChCl/malonic acid and ChCl/urea had significantly increased [81]. A lidocaine/ibuprofen eutectic system was suggested for the creation of transdermal delivery devices in 2014 [82]. A new THEDES derived from ChCl/menthol synthesized with three APIs—acetylsalicylic acid, phenylacetic acid, and benzoic acid was recently studied and further explored [83]. NMR analysis of the interactions between the THEDES components showed that the DES is created by hydrogen bonds generated between the API and menthol. The results showed that the APIs' solubility and permeability in THEDES may be significantly increased, indicating that these systems distribute the APIs more effectively [84]. Although very little functional and structural knowledge of THEDES is known, their promise in pharmaceutical development will undoubtedly result in an exponential increase in their use in the coming years. DESs are less hazardous, biocompatible, and readily synthesized from commonly accessible starting materials. DESs are referred to as “ILs analogues” because they have similar physicochemical characteristics. DESs are non-ionic compounds, but they may still be created by mixing the appropriate HBDs and HBAs, such as quaternary ammonium salts and metalhalides [31]. DESs are special because they can combine two easily biodegradable substances, HBAand HBD, in the optimum molar ratio [85]. They are also special because they are less expensive, do not require purification, and are both biodegradable and biocompatible [83,86,87]. Because of these properties, the prospective applications of DESshave already been investigated extensively since they emerged in the last several decades as practical green substitutes for aqueous and standard solvents. However, in the present study, we emphasize their potential influence on electrochemical applications. 3 Preparation and molecular interactions of DESs DESs are typically prepared using either of the two common methods: the heating or grinding method. The heating process involves continuously stirring while the chemicals are mixed and heated to create a homogenous liquid [88,89]. Typically, the heating temperature is in the 50–100 °C range. However, it was found that ChCland carboxylic acids-based solvents might degrade at high temperatures as a result of an esterification process, independent of the method of manufacturing [90]. In the grinding method, chemicals are combined at ambient temperature and then crushed in a mortar and pestle till a transparent solution is produced [91]. Another approach for the preparation of DES isfreeze-drying of aqueous solutions that contain DES constituents [92]. Recently developed evaporation technique that involved combining the elements of DESs with water, in conjunction with the process of vaporization at a temperature of 50 °C. The liquid that forms is then deposited in a desiccator with silica gel [74]. A more environmentally friendly microwave-assisted method was suggested for the rapid synthesis NADESswhile optimizing time and energy utilization [93]. NADESshave also recently been synthesized with the aid of ultrasound [94]. Physicochemical properties like phase behavior, viscosity, density,surface tension, conductivity, etc. of eutectic systems are strongly correlated with intermolecular interactions. When the forces between molecules across multiple components are greater than the initial forcesin each component results in the formation of eutectic liquids. Three main types of interactions often predominate in the creation of eutectic solvents, that are interactions between molecules through hydrogen bonding, Lewis acid-base interactions, and Van der Waals forces as shown in Fig. 4(b) [50]. The development and characteristics of eutectic liquids will be thoroughly explained in this part, along with a variety of intermolecular interactions for distinct eutectic liquids. The first category of interaction is hydrogen bonding. The majority of eutectic liquidsof the DES type are made via this powerful effect. This kind of eutectic combination must have at least an HBD, such ascarboxylic acid or amidemolecules, and one HBA, such as quaternary ammonium salts like ChCl or metal halides. Melting point depression upon mixing the DES components is mainly due to the charge delocalization process derived from the development of the whole hydrogen bonding network [95]. A well-established and high relative hydrogen bond network between HBA and HBD leads to a larger melting point depression [96]. The molar ratio can be determined by the ability of the HBD and HBAto form hydrogen bonds with one another. For example, inChCl and urea eutectic solvent the eutectic point is at 1:2, whereas, inChCl and thiourea mixture, theeutectic pointis at 1:3 [97]. As a result, by selecting various HBDs, the eutectic liquids can have their physicochemical properties tailored. Although the sizes ofurea and acetamide moleculesare comparable, the corresponding eutectic solventswith ZnCl2 show a substantial variation in viscosity. Due to its two NH2 functional groups, urea has more powerful hydrogen bonding than acetamide, which only has one NH2 functional group [98]. For DESs, a topological and DFT analysis of the electronic density was conducted, and according to the study's findings, the hydrogen-bonding network has the greatest impact on the melting point [99]. In a different study, COSMO-RS prediction for the chemical nature and interaction mechanism of glycol-based DESs was reported. In addition to the hydrogen bond interactions that had earlier been discovered, it was concluded that additional hydrogen bond interactions might have occurred during the production of DESs [95,100]. The second category of interactions is theLewis acid-base interaction. The Lewis theory of acid-base reactions describes Lewis acids as the electron pair acceptors whereasbases as the electron pairdonors [101]. In order to create a product with a coordinate covalent bond, a Lewis base can give pairs of electrons to a Lewis acid. As per the Lewis description, all cations and some chemical compounds like BF3 and PF3 are Lewis acids. On the other hand, bases include anions and substances like NH3, PH3, and C6H5CH2NH2 [102]. It is debatable whether the above hydrogen bond interaction belongs to the Lewis acid-base interactions or not. It is necessary to talk about this impact individually due to the significance of the unique interaction between hydrogen atoms andelectronegative atoms. The strength of the Lewis acid-base interactions is contingent upon the characteristics of the Lewis acid and base involved. These interactions can be as weak as hydrogen bonds (4 kJ mol−1) or as strong as certain covalent bonds (>100 kJ mol−1) [103]. In reality, it was not anticipated that the Lewis acid–base interaction in eutectic solvents would be powerful enough to promote a Lewis chemical reaction. It would be ideal if it just alters the coordination environment, producing a eutectic solventwith a low melting point. Alkali cations like Li+ andNa+ are often Lewis acids and may produce eutectic solvents with a range of molecules that include Lewis base groups, such as amides, andcarbonates. This is especially true for theLewis acidic lithium cation. For lithium energy storage devices, eutectic electrolytes constructed using various lithium salts such as LiTFSI and LiPF6 in conjunction with urea as the key ingredients, N-methylacetamide (NMAc), or acetamidemolecules have already been identified [104]. Developing eutectic solvents withminimal viscosity and higherionic conductivity would be easier if the charge delocalization of the TFSI− anion is of a higherdegree. The third category is van der Waals interactions, which include thedipole–dipole effect, dipole-induced dipole effect, and the London dispersion forces. Electrostatic mechanics are responsible for the first two of these effects. It can be seen that the dipole–dipole effectresults from permanent dipoles, while the dipole-induced dipole effectis represented as the attractive forcesbetween a polar and a nonpolar molecule, and the London dispersion force is generated by the induced dipoles resulting from the electrostaticpolarisations of interacting particles [105–107]. Among all the chemical forces thesevan der Waals interactions are weakest, with a magnitude of just 0.4 to 4 kJ mol−1, yet they may occur among any two molecules, so it is crucial to the system as a whole. Whenever the intermolecular interactions between the individual components are less than the van der Waals forces that are created, eutectic forms. Van der Waals forces, along with other interactions, largely contribute to modifying the physicochemical parameters of eutectic solvents. As a whole, these three interactions have an impact on how eutectic solvents are formed. In the context of this, it would be useful to elaborate on the formation process of eutectic electrolytes in order to conduct reasonable screening of these materials for use in various energy storage applications. We may then optimize the characteristics and phase behavior of eutectic electrolytes by adjusting the intermolecular interactions by modifications to the number of functionalities, substituents, and the composition of the mixture. Since the properties of DESs are their main point of interest, a thorough study of the physicochemical and electrochemical properties of these liquids is essential for the efficient design of DESsand for rationally exploring their applications. 4 Properties of DESs Scientists are showing high interest in DESs for many reasons, one of the primary reasons being the physicochemical and electrochemical properties of DESs. DESs have been explored for application in the industrial and energysector as possible solvents. Additionally, a large number of DESs may be produced by combining HBA and HBD in a variety of ways and making them customizable, that is why they are referred to as “designer solvents”. The physicochemical features of DESs are subject to being altered by using a wide variety of HBA and HBD mixtures, each with a distinct molar ratio. In addition to the ratio of HBA to HBD present, other factors that influence the physiochemical and electrochemicalproperties of DESs include temperature, the amount of water present, the purity of both HBA and HBD, the molar ratio of HBA to HBD, and the technique of synthesis [108]. In the context of their use as solvents in various applications, the investigation of the DESs'physicochemical and electrochemical propertiesis necessary and also, it is necessary to establish a good balance between these parameters. Therefore, the primary physicochemical properties including the phase behavior of the solvents, as well as their density, specific heat, viscosity, phase behavior, ionic conductivity, surface tension, electrochemical stability window, and green credentials of DESs, are described and explored in the following section (Fig. 5 ). 4.1 Phase behavior As mentioned earlier,DESs are notcomposed of chemical constituents but rather combinations of two or more distinct types of pure compounds. The melting point as a factor of mixture composition is shown on a binarysolid phase diagram (Fig. 6 ) for this system. Therefore, if we examine a binary combination of components A with B, the eutectic point is the composition and also the lowest melting point where the melting curves of both components meet. At this point, the melting points of both compounds are equal [109]. Fig. 7 illustrates open-literature solid–liquid equilibriaphase diagrams of terpenes-based systems [110]. Thymol and menthol have almost perfect solubility curves. DESs are defined as mixtures in which the melting point is below the ideal eutectic temperature [69,111]. Additionally, it was emphasized that a DES must remain in a liquid state at the operational temperature, even if this requires a different chemical makeup than that of a eutectic mixture. In order to find the optimal solubility curve, a phase diagram is required, as is an understanding of the melting characteristics of the pure compounds. However, still, very little information has been revealed on the thermodynamic behavior of DESs and moreover, DESs have a freezing temperature between − 70 and 150 °C [112]. The freezing point of such a mixture can be affected by a number of factors, including the HBD used [88,113], the composition of the organic salt as well as its anion, and the molar ratio of the organic salt to the HBD, therefore, this analysis can be crucial in discovering effective methods of utilizing DESs in various applications and can assist other researchers in designing DES systems that are tailored to their specific needs. [114]. The freezing point may also be affected by the preparation procedure, although the eutectic composition must stay constant [41,42]. However, the freezing point of a DESwas not found to be related to the melting points of its individual components [112]. However, the depression atthe freezing point( Δ T f ) was impacted by the HBD [97]. For instance, in a study, it was discovered that the depression atthe freezing point is larger whenthemolecular weight of the HBD is smaller [62]. However, some argued that instead of determining the temperature depression as the variation between the theoretical and actual eutectic point ( Δ T 2 ) , it should be calculated as the discrepancy between the melting point of a pure substance and the actual eutectic point according to a linear function ( Δ T 1 ) , because otherwise any mixture of compounds would be regarded as a DES [69,111,115–117]. Except for two places around the eutectic point, the solubility curve ofibuprofen deviates from ideality, whereas testosterone behaves well [118,119]. A few researchers have been studying the characteristics and phase behavior of biocompatible, water-based DESs that contain choline acetate, aspartate amino acid salts, and hydrogen aspartate, with water acting as the only HBD molecule [120]. These suggestions are made without any knowledge of this system's solid–liquid phase diagram or the departures from the thermodynamic idealness of its components [121–124]. 4.2 Density and specific heat Density is a key characteristic of solvents. The density of DESs varies with the HBD, the molar ratio of HBA:HBD, and the methods of preparation. According to the research, most DES have densities between 1.0 to 1.35 g cm−3 at 298.15 K [125], making them denser than water. The values shift most noticeably as HBA and HBD combinations are switched. The density of DESs made from the abundant HBA zinc chloride and other HBDs varies from 1.35 to 1.65 g cm−3 [89]. It has been observed that the densities of DESs made up of ChCl and different acids as HBDs ranges from 1.0 to 1.6 g cm−3 [126]. Recently seven machine learning techniques were utilized for the estimation of the density of 149 DESs [127]. In order to improve the precision of density forecasts, a library of 1410 density data points was gathered from open literature, representing 166 unique DESs at a range of temperatures and atmospheric pressures [128]. The density of the DESsvaries with temperature. A linear correlation between density and temperature was found using the equation [86,125] (1) ρ = a + b T where a and b are the fitting coefficients, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and ρ is the density in g cm−3. To a greater extent, the density of all DESs under study decreases as their temperature rises [129,130]. Higher temperatures cause the DES to have less packed molecules because more free space is available there [131,132].The DES aqueous solution exhibited the same characteristics after being diluted with water [125]. The density of aqueous solutions of DESs steadily dropped when water was added to pure DESs because hydrogen bonding between constituents of DESs was suddenly diminished [133,134]. The same impact of hydrogen bond dissolution with increasing temperature was observed. This impact led to a lower density of DESs, a dislocation of their constituent parts, and a rise in their free volume. The PC-SAFT and Free Volume Theory were employed to calculate and predict physico-chemical characteristics (such as density and excess volume) and to examine how temperature changes, alcohol chain length, and HBD length influence mixture configuration. Hydrophobic DES(for the extraction of boron from aqueous solutions, 2-methyl-2,4-pentanediol (MPD) or 1-decanol (Dec) are used as the HBDsand menthol (Men) or thymol (Thy) as the HBAs) densities were measured at various temperatures (Fig. 8 a) [135]. The ability of DESs to absorb and transfer heat is crucial for many chemical engineering processes, including reactors and separation units. Heat plays a crucial role in a wide range of chemical reactions and separation processes, and the heat capacities of DESs can have a significant impact on the efficiency and effectiveness of these operations. Therefore, understanding and optimizing the heat capacities of DESs is an important area of research and development. Due to the vast number of components that can be used as HBAs or HBDs, and the range of molar ratios that can be used to create DESs, it is practically impossible to experimentally investigate all possible DESs. Therefore, a generalized model can accurately predict the physical properties of DESs in order to understand and optimize their use in several applications [136]. As the weight of a compound increases, it generally takes more energy to raise its temperature by one degree. Therefore, the heat capacity of a compound is expected to be directly related to its molecular mass. This principle has been taken into account in the proposed model (Fig. 8b–e) [136]. The specific heat capacities of DESs made from ethanediol and betaine/L-carnitine were examined and were found to correlate well with a second-order empirical equation. Increasing the temperature or ethanediol content in the DESs led to an increase in their specific heat capacities. The accuracy of the correlations was high, with average absolute relative deviations (AARDs) not exceeding 0.22% [132]. 4.3 Viscosity and ionic conductivity Viscosity refers to the internal resistance of a fluid to flow, and so characterizes the internal friction encountered by flowing fluid. The mass transport within eutectic solvents is significantly influenced by viscosity, making it a crucial factor in determining the appropriateness of DESs for specific applications such as electrochemical applications. Due to their practical significance, DESs' viscosity has been widely documented. Temperature-dependent viscosity values are crucial for calculating equipment performance and for comprehending activation energy and mass transport processes [137]. The viscosity of DES is shown to be proportional to temperature according to the Arrhenius equation [86,138]. (2) ln η = ln η ∞ + E η RT where the temperature (T) and viscosity ( η ) are related by the gas constant (R), with an activation energy ( E η ) and a pre-exponential constant ( η ∞ ) also playing a role in determining the viscosity. By putting the viscosity at different temperatures into this equation, we may determine the relationship between the intensity of molecular interactions and temperature in DES [53]. The majority of the DESs that were investigated had viscosities that were more than 100 cP, which is much greater than that of water at normal temperature. The presence of a robust and extensive interaction between components through hydrogen bonding may be what causes the high viscosity of DESs, this might be one of the key driving reasons behind it. Because of the extensive web of DESs, the movement of free species within the DES is restricted [139]. The high viscosity of DESs may also be attributed to the following additional factors: (i) interactions through van der Waals forces or electrostatic means; (ii) the difference in size between ions and the smaller spaces within DESs; and (iii) the available unoccupied space [86]. The viscosity of DESs is primarily determined by the following four key factors: The make-up of the DES's components: the chemical characteristics of HBAs and HBDs are the primary factors that determine the viscosities of DESs. The ChCl:ethylene glycol (1:4) DES mixture exhibited the least resistance to flow with a viscosity of 19 cP at 293.15 K, but the viscosity of DES rose to 8500 cP at 298.15 K when HBD was substituted with ZnCl2 [140]. The HBA and HBD molar ratio: in general, greater molar ratios of HBA to HBD led to the formation of DESs with higher viscosities. Because DESs have such compact structures, the amount of free space that is available diminishes. The smaller quantity of available free volume causes DESs to move their molecules more slowly, which results in a greater degree of viscosity. The molar ratio of HBD has a direct effect on the viscosity of DESs; as it rises, the viscosity of DESs decreases. When the molar ratio of glycerol in a ChCl/glycerol DES is increased, the DES will have a higher viscosity. At a temperature of 293.15 K, it was observed that the viscosity measurements of DES solutions with a 1:2, 1:3, and 1:4 molar ratio were approximately 503, 450, and 376 centipoise, respectively. The addition of ChCl to glycerol disrupts the hydrogen bonding, which in turn results in the reduction of viscosity of DES [141]. The amount of water that DESs contain: when determining the viscosity of DES, the water content of DES is one of the most significant parameters to take into consideration. Because the majority of DESs are very hygroscopic, it is necessary to remove the amount of water that is present in DESs. In the addition of a 0.1-mole fraction of water, the viscosity of DES that was constituted of ChCl:urea (1:2) dropped down to 200.6 cP from its previous value of 527.3 cP. The addition of water caused a reduction in the viscosity of DESs that ranged from 10 to 30 times lower, depending on the HBDs. After absorbing 19.40% of moisture, the ChCl: oxalic acid (1:1) mixture had a viscosity that was about 44 cP lower, down from 5363 cP. It is possible to adjust the consistency of DES by mixing in a certain quantity of water [138,141]. Temperature: because it has been shown that the viscosity of DESs reduces as the temperature increases, it is possible to employ DESs that have a high viscosity at room temperature in applications that take place at temperatures that are higher. In the temperature ranges 298–328 K, viscosity experienced a significant decrease as ChCl:urea (1:2) dropped from an initial reading of 750 to 95 mPa s, ChCl:glycerol (1:2) dropped from 259 to 52 mPa s, ChCl:malonic acid dropped from 1124 to 161 mPa s and ChCl:glucose dropped from 7992 to 262 mPa s [60]. Recently, researchers have been studying hydrophobic eutectic solvents that are based on 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) and natural phenolic compounds. The physical properties of these mixtures can be affected by solutes that alter the nature of the existing hydrogen-bonded network, particularly through the protonation of phen [142]. In addition, the formation of hydrogen bonds between the components can increase the viscosity of the DES, as hydrogen bonds are strong and can resist the movement of the components. The viscosity of DESs can also be influenced by the concentration of the components, the temperature, and the presence of other substances in the DES [143]. Overall, the high viscosity of DESs can make them difficult to handle and use in some applications [144]. Several methods have been put forth to decrease the density and as a result, improve the feasibility of using DESs in industrial settings. The combination of DES and water leads to a malleable composition arising from the connection between the hydrogen bond's elements. This is one potential approach, and we will delve into it further later in this article utilizing the hole theory [145]. There are several other ways to reduce the viscosity of DESs, such as modifying the components, using additives, and increasing the temperature. Researchers have found that changing the ratio of the components in a DES can alter its viscosity, and the use of low-molecular-weight additives, such as urea, can disrupt the hydrogen bonding between the components and reduce viscosity. Increasing the temperature can also cause the components of the DES to become more mobile, leading to a decrease in viscosity. Recently, the development of DESs that are comprised of ILs as hydrogen bond acceptors has been a topic of interest. These DESs have been found to have significantly lower viscosities (<20 cp) compared to pure room temperature ILs that are conventionally used [146]. In DESs with a ratio of 1:7 of KI to EG, the most remarkable conductivity (1.22 mS cm−1) and the least viscosity (39.77 cP) have recently been noted [147]. When using DESs as electrolytes for electrochemical systems, a low viscosity is desirable because it promotes fast mass transport. In functional material synthesis also, the viscosity of the solvent plays a crucial role in adjusting mass transport properties and controlling the formation of nanostructures [148]. The different viscosities of DESs can direct the growth of nanostructures with various shapes and high-index facets, which can affect their catalytic activities. Also, to improve the kinetics and efficiency of battery recycling, it is crucial to control the viscosity of the DES [149]. Ionic conductivity measures a material's ability to allow the flow of ions or current through ionic conduction. Particular focus has been made on investigating the conductivity of DESs for energy storage applications, including employing them as improved electrolytes in redox-flow batteries [150,151]. Unlike high-temperature molten salts, DESs typically have a lower level of ionic conductivity and the disparity can be attributed to the size of ions and the thickness of the fluid, both of which are interconnected with the concept of hole theory. Hole theory can also be used to explain how the conductivity of DESs can be affected by the dissolution of other compounds, such as NiCl2 [114]. The size of the dissolved ions can either increase or decrease the size of holes in the DES, which in turn can either increase or decrease the viscosity and ionic conductivity of the DES. Recently studied, DESs that are comprised of ILs as HBAs have ionic conductivities of greater than 5 mS cm−1, which makes them suitable for use in a variety of applications that require high conductivity [146]. 4.4 Electrochemical stability window and electrochemical behavior The “Electrochemical Stability Window” (ESW) is a measure of the range of potentials at which a solvent is stable and does not undergo chemical decomposition. DESs have been found to have a wide electrochemical stability window, making them attractive for use in electrochemical applications such as electroplating, electrosynthesis, and electrodeposition. Thus, the electrochemical behavior of DESs at an interface with an electrode is a crucial property in electrochemical applications. Researchers investigated the electrochemical characteristics of ChCl-based DESs where cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy were used [152]. They found that the double-layer differential capacitance of the DESs, which reflects their electrochemical behavior, is dependent on the material of the working electrode and increased with temperature, except for gold electrodes where a crossing point in the capacitance curve was observed. The researchers also examined the electrical interfaces of six different ChCl-based DESs with different HBDs at a mercury electrode. They found that the DESs did not exhibit any electrical peaks that could be traced back to the transfer of charges within the tested potential range, although a pair of distinct peaks were noticed in the ChCl-urea DES at approximately 0 Volts, which was tentatively attributed to the film formation at the mercury electrode’s surface. The negative limit of polarization or potential, over which the electrolyte can be polarized, was found to depend on the HBDs and increase in the following order: 1,3-propanediol, urea, EG, and 1,2-propanediol. The authors also found that increasing the temperature of the DESs lowered the electrochemical window (EW) and raised the measured capacitive current or the range of potentials over which the electrolyte can be electrochemically stable. Although the EW of these DESs is smaller than some conventional ILs, they're larger than expected for a protic solvent like DESs, and the reduction of protons was not observed, suggesting that protons are tightly bound with chloride ions in these systems [153]. To fully harness the chemical reactivity of a solute in a solution, it is crucial to comprehend its level of activity. The plot of E vs. ln(m) was utilized to examine the activity of protons, copper ions, and silver ions in ChCl:EG. They demonstrated that the change in redox potential for these three solutes in relation to molality follows the Nernst equation for an ideal solution. (3) E = RT nF l n m 1 γ 1 m 2 γ 2 A number of variables are included in the equation, including the equilibrium redox potential (E), gas constant (R), Faraday constant (F), absolute temperature (T), and the number of electrons (n). The molality of the solute (m) is also included, with 1 and 2 denoting the reference cell and test cell, respectively. The Ag/Ag+ and Cu2+/Cu+ redox couple exhibits almost ideal behavior, which suggests that the ionic matrix in the solution effectively protects the metal ions from interacting with each other. This allows the ions to behave independently. By taking a reference electrode as a standard DES hydrogen electrode, few researchers were able to calculate the standard redox potentials for the Ag+/Ag and Cu2+/Cu+ systems in DESs as +0.034 and +0.58 V, respectively [154]. The deviation from the typical redox potentials in water is believed to be a result of the distinct way the metals are combined in the two different solvents. Shifting our focus to recent progress made where researchers mainly targeted the electrochemical window to be wide, so that DESs become the best choice in electrochemical applications in comparison to other choices available, many DESs systems have been found which provide comparative or even better results than the competition. Cosidering Zn salts, a study found that Zn(TFSI)2/Ace had a broader anodic stability range of 2.4 V (compared to Zn/Zn2+), surpassing DESs that used various other common Zn salts (such as Zn(ClO4)2, Zn(CH3COO)2, and Zn(BF4)2) that contained different anions. One study found that DESs based on ChCl and alkylammonium chlorides had an electrochemical stability window ranging from −1.4 to +3.4 V versus a reference electrode [155]. Another study found that among the investigational electrochemical potential windows (EPWs) of ChCl, ChBr, ChI, and methyl urea-based DESs, the largest potential window was found in the DES made of ChCl and methyl urea [156]. DESscontaining alkali metalsalts and EG, Gly, or PEG have been created. electrochemical windows of 3–4 V, meeting electrochromic devices (ECD) suitability standards [157]. EG- and LiTFSI-based DESs were examined in another investigation. Synthesized DESs have better characteristics (high EW(∼4.5 V against Li+/Li)) (Fig. 9 a) [158]. Another study offers two DESs for usage in activated carbon supercapacitors (ACS) at 25 °C that are based on lithium and sodium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imides in combination with N-methylacetamide and formamide as electrolytes. These DESs have high thermal stability (up to around 150 °C), a large electrochemical window (E > 2.5 V), moderate viscosity (11.3 mPa s), and ionic conductivity in the range of 3–4 mS cm−1 [159]. Another promising result as the Fig. 9(b) (ChCl is HBA and 1, 2-butanediol, 1, 3-butanediol, 1, 4-butanediol asHBDs in DES-1, DES-2, and DES-3, respectively) shows the voltage of 2 V for ACSwhen DES-1 is used as the electrolyte, as well as its specific capacitance of 116 F g−1 and energy density of 16.14 Wh kg−1 [160]. And, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) testing showed that all three DESs had ESW in the range of 3.8–4 V, similar to pure ILs and much higher than the potential windows of IL and organic solvent mixtures, which are frequently used as electrolytes in DESs containing ILs as HBAs [146]. 4.5 Solubility The ionic and relatively polar nature of DESs allows for the high solubility of many ionic species, such as metal salts. This solubility has made DESs useful in the synthesis of functional nanomaterials through both chemical and electrochemical approaches for energy storage and conversion [161,162]. DESs based on ChCl are particularly popular because a variety of metal precursors are highly soluble in them, they are inexpensive, and they have a very low vapor pressure. These precursors, like NiCl2·6H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, CoCl2·6H2O, H2PtCl6·6H2O, and La(NO3)3, are highly soluble in ChCl-based DESs, allowing for the creation of electrocatalysts and electrode materials with particular morphologies and characteristics [163]. Additionally, DESs can dissolve organic molecules considerably more effectively than water, which is advantageous for the creation of carbonaceous materials. There have been several publications in recent years comparing the performance of DESs with that of acids in the dissolving of typical metal oxides. Due to this, precious metals from used batteries are being recycled using DESs [164]. It has been discovered that raising the temperature significantly enhances DESs' capacity to dissociate, as seen by rising metal ion concentrations inside the DESs. Metal oxides have been shown to be more soluble in DESs when the salt-to-HBD ratio is reduced [165]. This breakthrough could potentially be beneficial for a plethora of applications that hinge on the metal oxides' ability to dissolve in DESs. 4.6 Surface tension In relation to a material's propensity to have the lowest surface area feasible, surface tension measures the amount of energy needed to raise a certain material's surface area [166]. The phenomenon of surface tension is particularly notable in fluid substances as a result of the interactions between molecules at the surface. There are various methods for determining its presence, such as utilizing a Wilhelmy plate, a Du Noüy ring, or a pendant drop [167–169]. In the realm of DESs, the cohesive forces at the interface between the liquid and its surrounding medium can be examined in conjunction with other parameters such as mass density, internal resistance to flow, and ionic conductivity to comprehend the impact of variations in composition and temperature on the molecular surroundings of the DES. The property of surface tension is crucial because it is closely linked to the strength of the intermolecular forces between hydrogen bond donors and corresponding salts. As a result, liquids with high viscosity typically exhibit elevated surface tensions. A research project evaluated the surface tension of three ChCl-based DESs that featured phenol, levulinic acid, and EG as HBDs. [170]. The findings indicated that the surface tension of the DES (calculated as 45.66 mN m−1 at 298.15 K and 101.3 kPa) was less than that of pure ethylene glycol (calculated as 48.90 mN m−1). This pattern was also noticed in other ChCl:HBA combinations and the decline in surface tension from the pure HBD to the DES was ascribed to the inclusion of ChCl [171]. An investigation was conducted to investigate the impact of ChCl on DESs by evaluating the physical characteristics of mixtures of ChCl and D-fructose. The findings indicated that the surface tension was most minimal at a proportion of 1:1 (ChCl 50 mol%) in terms of molarity, with a measurement of 70.4 mN m−1, as opposed to a ratio of 2.5:1, which had a measurement of 75.0 mN m−1 [172]. For the ChCl:D-fructose DES, the eutectic composition was determined to be 2:1 through freezing point measurements. Models based on observation and experimentation have been created to estimate the tension on the surface of DESs, which can be useful for comparing them to experimental measurements [173,174]. Mostly reported DESs until now have surface tension values ranging between 35 and 75 mN m−1 at 25 °C. Additionally, the surface tension linearly declines as temperature rises. 4.7 Vapor pressure and nonflammability Vapor pressure is a measure of the pressure exerted by the vapor phase of a substance in a state of thermodynamic balance with its condensed forms. It is an important property to consider when selecting a solvent, as it determines the volatility of the solvent and can affect its handling and storage. Historically, DESs have been thought to have negligible vapor pressure due to their similarities with ILs, which are known for their low vapor pressure. DESs do exhibit significant vapor pressure values, however, they are often lower than those of popular volatile organic solvents like acetonitrile and toluene, as shown by recent investigations. Several studies have measured the vapor pressure of DESs using various techniques. For example, in a study, isobaric vapor–liquid equilibrium was used to measure the vapor pressure of a DES composed of N-methylacetamide and lithium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)-imide at 313 K. Researchers found that the vapor pressure of DES was significantly higher than that of typical aprotic ILs, measuring 20 Pascals. However, it was still significantly lower than the vapor pressure of water at the same temperature, which was 7400 Pascals [175]. A separate examination utilized isothermogravimetry at 373 K to calculate the vapor pressures of various DESs, such as reline (1.33 Pa), glyceline (11.6 Pa), a mixture of 1:2 diethylethanolammonium chloride and urea (1.8 Pa), a combination of 1:2 N,N-diethylethanolammonium chloride and glycerol (16.9 Pa), and a blend of 1:2 methyltriphenylphosphonium bromide and glycerol (9.9 Pa) [176]. These results show that the vapor pressure of DESs may vary greatly depending on the particular components and their proportions in the combination, and they are similar to those discovered by Boisset et al. Another study classified liquid by decreasing vapor pressure using isothermogravimetry, including triglyme, short-chain and long-chain polyethylene glycols (PEGs), DESs, protic and polymeric ILs, traditional aprotic ILs (such as dialkylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imides), and dicationic ILs [177]. According to the research, DESs exhibited greater vapor pressures than protic ILs, polymeric ILs, and traditional aprotic ILs but lower vapor pressures than short-chain and long-chain PEGs. It was discovered that ethaline was the most volatile among the idealized DESs (i.e., reline, ethaline, and glyceline), which was predicted given the greater vapor pressure of ethylene glycol compared to glycerol. The total vapor pressure of six hydrophobic DESs at 373 K was recently measured by scientists using headspace gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (HS-GC–MS). The separation of each component's contributions to the total vapor of the DES is made possible by HS-GC–MS, giving essential information that is not possible with thermogravimetric analysis [178]. The examined DESs had total vapor pressures that varied from 55.5 Pa for a 2:1 decanoic acid:lidocaine mixture to 540.9 Pa for a 1:1 decanoic acid:menthol mixture. These values are greater than those of ordinary aprotic ILs but lower than those of usual volatile organic solvents. Overall, these experiments show that the vapor pressure of DESs are in fact much greater than those of their IL equivalents, though lower than those of conventional volatile organic solvents. The vapor pressure of a DES can vary significantly depending on the specific components and their ratios in the mixture, as well as the temperature. It is important to consider vapor pressure when selecting a DES for a specific application, as it can affect the handling and storage of the solvent. Due to their nonflammability and possible usage as secure electrolytes in energy storage systems like high-temperature batteries, DESs have drawn interest in recent years. This is partly because DESs have a high thermal breakdown temperature and a low vapor pressure [179]. Because they are less volatile and less likely to decompose than other solvents, DESs act as excellent nonflammable solvents. Additionally, DESs' low vapor pressure is advantageous for material synthesis since it enables material preparation under ambient pressure, doing away with any potential safety issues brought on by high solvent pressure [180]. All things considered, DESs are a desirable option for application in energy storage devices and material synthesis due to their low vapor pressure and high thermal breakdown temperature. 4.8 Refractive index and polarity The refractive index ( n ) is a characteristic of a substance that indicates the degree to which the velocity of light is altered as it permeates through a medium ( ν ) compared to the speed of light in a vacuum ( c ) [181]. It follows the Snell’s Law principle given as (4) n = c ν This property is important for understanding the optical and electrical properties of DESs. Despite the fact that there aren't many studies on the refractive indices of DESs, several teams have used this method to conduct early research and gathered important insights. For instance, it was discovered in one of the finding that the refractive index of DESs containing glycerol and ChClat various molar ratios varied with temperature, with the eutectic ratio having the maximum refractive index throughout a temperature range of 15–55 °C [182]. In another study, it was found that the refractive index of DESs containing tetrabutylammonium chloride as the HBA and phenylacetic acid or propionic acid as the HBD varied depending on the type of HBD. DESs containing the bulkier phenylacetic acid HBD had a higher refractive index than those containing the propionic acid HBD. The electrical characteristics of DESs may also be investigated using the refractive index. In a study, the experimental refractive indexes of L-proline- and betaine-based DESs were used to calculate the molar refractivity, which can provide insight into the electrical properties of these DESs [183]. Overall, the refractive index is a useful tool for understanding the properties and behavior of DESs. Polarity is an important property of solvents, as it reflects their ability to solvate various compounds. However, the polarity of DESs has not been extensively studied until recently. The polarity of DESs can be estimated using solvatochromic parameters, which measure the shift in the absorption of UV–vis light by dyes in response to changes in solvent polarity [184]. The most commonly used scales for measuring polarity are the Dimroth-Reichardt scale (ET and ETN) and the Kamlet-Taft scale (the ability to donate hydrogen bonds α, the capability to accept hydrogen bonds β, and the dipole moment/polarizability π*) [184–186]. It is important to note that these polarity scales are not universal and are probe-dependent, meaning that they cannot be directly compared when using different solvatochromic probes [187]. Understanding the polarity of DESs is crucial for identifying their suitability for various applications, and further research is needed to fully characterize and optimize the use of DESs in different contexts. 4.9 Green credential While DESs have often been referred to as “green solvents” due to their low vapor pressure, this is not necessarily the case [188]. In fact, the toxicity and biotoxicity of DESs have been investigated, and it has been found that they are not inherently “green” due to their potential toxicity. There are over 106 different formulations of DESs, and some of them may be composed of benign constituents and have low inherent toxicity, while others may contain metal salts with inherent toxicity [189]. The majority of DESs applications have been in the field of metal finishing, and their toxicity must be compared to the aqueous mineral acids they aim to replace. A study found that a DES composed of ChCl and EG was not harmful to the environment in electroplating applications, although the environmental impact was largely because the products produced during the electrolysis process and the solutions used for washing both contain heavy metals [190]. The study found that the primary contributor to the environmental impact of the process was the loss of process solution, known as drag-out, caused by the high viscosity of the DES. This effect was found to be three times more significant than that of traditional solutions. Although the DES made up of ChCl and EG did not pose a significant risk to the environment compared to many other ILs, it was suggested that rinse water from its use could be treated with ion exchange in order to remove any remaining metals. In a survey study of six potential DESs, it was found that ChCl/Gly mixtures have the most environment friendly properties and can be produced from renewable sources. ChCl/U DESs also have good biodegradability, but their sustainability is hindered by a lack of feasible synthetic pathways from non-fossil fuel sources. The results of ChCl/EG DES systems are highly promising in terms of safety, decomposability, and yield, however, it remains unverified whether they can be manufactured on a significant scale utilizing renewable energy sources. Overall, ChCl/Gly mixtures are the most sustainable option, followed by ChCl/U and ChCl/EG DESs [191]. In a separate study, the scientists observed the formation of a variety of derivatives, including 2-methyl-1,3-dioxolane, as well as various chlorinated substances, such as chloromethane, chloroform, and dichloromethane [192]. However, they did not observe the production of chlorine gas at the anode. It was found that the presence of water could decrease the formation of chlorinated compounds, and the use of sacrificial agents could decrease the formation of 2-methyl-1,3-dioxolane. Despite this, the presence of these chlorinated products had a significant negative impact on the environment. One of the properties that make DESs appealing for some applications is their low vapor pressure, which can help to reduce their emission into the atmosphere. However, it is worth noting that DESs are partially miscible with water and are hygroscopic, which means that they may still end up in aquatic environments. To truly be “green,” a method for recycling DESs needs to be established as well as methods for removing DESs from aqueous environments [193]. To counter this issue Hydrophobic DESs are a relatively new type of DESs that have gained popularity due to their ability to work in direct contact with water. It is widely acknowledged that care must be taken when designing these compounds to ensure they are stable in water [194]. In addition to their environmental impacts, the toxicity and biotoxicity of DESs have also been investigated. Studies have shown that some DESs can have low acute and chronic toxicity, while others may have higher toxicity due to the contribution of metal salts. For example, a DES composed of ChCl and EG was found to have low acute and chronic toxicity in a study, while a DES composed of ZnCl2 and EG had higher acute toxicity in the same study. It is important to consider the toxicity of DESs when selecting them for specific applications and to properly handle and dispose of them to minimize potential harm to human health and the environment. It is essential to consider that the harmfulness and harmful impact on cells of ILs and DESs is greatly contingent on the starting materials employed. Studies have found that the harmfulness of DESs is usually greater than that of the individual components utilized to create them. For instance, it was observed that 10 nauplii cells could not survive for more than 5.32 and 10.13 min in ChCl/glycerol and ChCl/ethylene glycol solutions, respectively. However, when exposed to the individual components (ChCl, glycerol, and ethylene glycol) independently, the cells were able to endure for longer durations (40, 37, 13.04, 53.24 min) [195–197]. An investigation was conducted utilizing the method of life-cycle assessment (LCA) to evaluate the environmental impact of a ChCl/U-based solvent, referred to as reline. The study contrasted reline's ecological footprint when utilized in the oxidation of alcohol to acetophenone, with that of commonly employed organic solvents such as methanol, dichloromethane (DCM), and ethyl acetate. The results indicate that reline has a greater overall impact on the environment when compared to methanol and ethanol, yet a smaller ecological footprint when compared to DCM and ethyl acetate. Furthermore, the materials utilized in the synthesis of reline significantly contribute to its environmental effect when compared to other procedures. Additionally, LCA of four other ChCl-based DESs were performed by replacing urea with other compounds, among which ChCl/citric acid DES had the highest environmental impact [198]. Recently a new class of DESs named NADESs has been discovered which shows nontoxic, environmentally sustainable, and biodegradable nature due to the fact that it is composed of compounds of natural origin. One of the main HBA, ChCl is commonly used in the preparation of NADES, and it is extensively used as an additive in chicken feed. NADES are also used in solubilizing drugs for oral administration in rats and in the production of biodegradable polyesters with antibacterial properties [199]. Studies have revealed that some of the ingredients used to make DESs and NADESs can be harmful, despite them being among the most ecologically safe non-aqueous solvents. Some substances also cannot be regarded as readily biodegradable. It is crucial to comprehend the mechanisms underlying the toxic effects and good biocompatibility of these solvents, find constituents with improved biosecurity and biocompatibility and create a database of environmentally safe DESs and NADESs derived from these components based on their toxic effects and bio-compatibility in order to fully utilize these solvents and broaden their applications [200]. Other concerns related to the environmental sustainability of DESs that needs to be thoroughly studied include energy consumption, cost, and synthesis, regeneration and renewability, flammability, and safety [197]. Further investigation is essential to completely grasp the hazards and advantages of utilizing DESs and to develop safe and effective methods for their use, recycling, and disposal. 5 Comparative analysis of conventional liquid electrolytes and DESs in electrochemical energy storage Conventional electrolytes, such as aqueous electrolytes, organic electrolytes, and ILs, have been widely used in electrochemical applications due to their ability to conduct electricity and facilitate the transport of ions [201–203]. However, these electrolytes often have limitations in terms of toxicity, flammability, and other properties that can affect their performance and safety [204,205]. Herein, we will have a brief insight into the fundamentals of conventional electrolytes and compare them to the emerging class of DESs, which have gained attention due to their unique properties [206]. 5.1 Organic electrolytes Organic electrolytes, also known as organic liquid electrolytes (OLEs), have a long history of their usage in energy storage devices. The first use of OLEs can be traced back to the development of the first lithium-ion battery in the early 1990 s. Since then, they have become an essential component in a wide range of energy storage devices, including portable electronics, electric vehicles, and renewable energy systems. OLEs are electrolytes made from a combination of lithium salts and organic solvents. These electrolytes are responsible for transferring ions between the electrodes in an energy storage device, allowing for charge and discharge [207]. Classic lithium salts include LiClO4, LiPF6, and LiTFSI, while common organic solvents include propylene carbonate, ethylene carbonate, ethyl methyl carbonate, and dimethyl carbonate. OLEs have several advantages that make them a popular choice for energy storage devices. One major benefit is their high ionic conductivity, which allows for the efficient transfer of ions between the electrodes. This leads to improved charge–discharge performance and overall energy density [208]. In addition, OLEs have a wide electrochemical stability window, meaning they can withstand a wide range of operating conditions without degrading. This makes them suitable for use in a range of different devices, including those with high-rate discharge requirements. Despite these benefits, OLEs do have some drawbacks when using them in energy storage devices. One major issue is their relatively high cost compared to other electrolyte options. In addition, OLEs can be prone to thermal instability, which can lead to safety concerns. This is especially true for solvents with high boiling points, as they can decompose at high temperatures and release toxic gases. Another drawback of OLEs is their relatively low energy density compared to other electrolyte options, such as solid-state electrolytes [209]. This is due in part to their relatively low ionic conductivity at low temperatures, which can lead to a decrease in performance in cold environments. OLEs also tend to have a lower operating temperature range compared to other electrolyte options, meaning they may not be suitable for use in extreme temperature conditions. Acetonitrile has been widely used as a non-aqueous solvent for electrolytes in redox flow batteries (RFBs). This is due to evidence that acetonitrile exhibits open circuit cell potentials up to 2.6 V, which is high in comparison to other non-aqueous solvents. However, the energy efficiency of RFBs using acetonitrile as an electrolyte has been limited to 40%. Additionally, acetonitrile is relatively expensive and has a high vapor pressure, which can be problematic in certain applications [210]. Due to these difficulties, researchers are looking for non-aqueous alternatives that may provide a wide potentialwindow and a vast range of functionality without the limitations shown by the organic solvents. One such alternative is the use of DESs in RFBs, which have been found to be a promising solution to these issues. 5.2 Aqueous electrolytes Aqueous energy storage devices offer immense potential for large-scale energy storage as they are highly safe, environment friendly, and economic [211]. The major advantage of aqueous electrolytes is the non-flammable nature of aqueous systems as it solves the issues concerned with the safety of batteries. The facile fabrication of the energy storage systems based on aqueous electrolytes also makes them attractive for large-scale energy storage [212]. The short electrochemical window of water, which is around 1.23 V for pure water, limits the commercial usage of aqueous electrolytes, while organic electrolytes provide a broad electrochemical window of 3–5 V. This major drawback of aqueous electrolytes is due to the high hydrogen potential and low oxidation potential thereby limiting the use of redox materials as anodes and cathodes. The water decomposition in aqueous electrolytes results in irreversible electrochemical reactions and hence halting the commercial use of aqueous electrolytes in energy storage systems. Albeit, in the case of non-aqueous electrolytes there is the formation of solid electrolyte interphase between the electrolyte and the electrode which is formed due to the decomposition of the electrode instead of the electrolyte unlike in the case of aqueous electrolyte [213,214]. As the decomposition products from water are unable to deposit on the surface of the electrode in case of dilute aqueous electrolytes, thereby lacking the formation of such a defensive interface, eventually resulting in low voltage and low energy density. Moreover, the research to improve the aqueous electrolytes is still thriving as various ways have been reported to improve the electrochemical window as well as to reduce the redox activity of water. Lately, there has been a notable surge of interest in using “water-in-salt” (WiS) electrolytes for advanced high-performance energy storage devices (ESDs) due to their environmentally friendly nature. The WiS electrolyte boasts a broad electrochemical stability window (ESW), superior electrochemical performance, high safety, and non-flammability in comparison to conventional “salt-in-water” electrolytes [215]. Some of the other methods to improve the aqueous electrolytes include using redox-active additives. These redox additives can be cathode additives as well as anode additives. These redox additives are oxidized or reduced at the respective electrodes during the charging process prior to the decomposition of water and reverse reactions occur on the electrode surface during the discharge process. Recent advancements in the field have led to the utilization of a highly concentrated water-based electrolyte composed of LiNO3 in DESs. This solution offers an expanded range of electrochemical stability, reaching up to 2.55 V, while also being cost-efficient [216]. Consequently, the electrochemical window of aqueous electrolytes is widened. For instance, Hwang et al used an aqueous ferrocyanide/ferricyanide redox electrolyte which enhanced the electrochemical window, and consequently, energy density was also improved.
