Other redox additives that have been documented include quinones, LiFSI, NaFSI, copper salts, phenylenediamine, halides, and vanadium complexes [217,218]. Nevertheless, in some cases, where the redox of these additives is irreversible there is unwanted Coulombic efficiency as well as discontented cycling stability. 5.3 ILs vs. DESs It's essential to acknowledge that although DES and ILs are frequently utilized synonymously in some scholarly texts, they relate to two distinct types of solvents [28]. ILs are a distinct category of salt that maintains a fluid consistency at ambient temperature, containing solely ions that are held together by ionic bonds. Although their discovery dates back to the dawn of the 20th century, it wasn't until much later that their potential as substitutes for traditional organic solvents was fully acknowledged. ILs have a wide range of potential uses, including as electrolytes in batteries, lubrication additives, and in the synthesis of inorganic and nanomaterials. One of the main advantages of ILs is their low to negligible vapor pressure, which makes them almost non-emitting to the atmosphere. This makes them an attractive option for certain industrial processes where vapor emissions may be a concern. ILs may be tailored for interactions with various chemicals and materials and are also thermally and electrochemically stable. This makes them a versatile solvent option for a wide range of applications. They can be synthesized with varying functional groups or alkyl chain lengths, which allows for the creation of “designer solvents” that can be tailored for specific tasks. Lately, many studies show the task-specific use of ILs, for instance, a method of synthesizing a nanostructured Li-rich fluoride solid electrolyte using low-temperature IL was explored. The IL acts as a binder and improves interfacial ion transport and the electrolyte is successfully used in a Li/Li3GaF6/LiFePO4 cell, showing potential for solid-state batteries [219]. A similar study presented an IL-based approach that facilitates the formation of nanostructured open framework fluorides with potential use as battery electrodes [220]. Another study reports the synthesis of a dehydrated iron fluoride conversion cathode for Li-ion batteries using an ionothermal fluorination method with a microphase-separation-type IL [221]. Further, in a study, IL-coated nanostructured Li-rich fluoride serves as a high-ion conductivity solid electrolyte additive that inhibits dendrite growth at the Li metal anode [222]. These examples of tunability show why ILs have gained so much attention in recent years. Despite the early excitement for ILs, several of their first presumed attractive characteristics have now been called into doubt in recent years [223]. One of the main drawbacks of ILs is their high cost, which is due in part to the multi-step synthesis process required to produce them. This process can be time-consuming and expensive, and often generates waste products that must be disposed of. Additionally, many ILs are toxic, non-biodegradable, and unsustainable, which may make them less attractive for certain industrial applications. They may also pose a risk to human health if not handled properly, as some ILs are highly corrosive and can cause skin irritation or burns. Another major drawback of ILs is their high hygroscopicity, which means that they are prone to absorbing moisture from the air. This can be a problem in certain applications, as the presence of moisture can affect the stability and performance of the IL. Additionally, some ILs are sensitive to moisture and may decompose or react with other substances when exposed to them. This can be a concern in certain industrial processes where the IL may be used over a long period of time [224]. DESs are a type of solvent that has been shown to have some potential advantages over ILs in certain applications. The components are simply mixed together to create DES, producing no waste and require no refining procedures. This makes them significantly less expensive and more environmentally friendly than ILs. DES is also typically less toxic and more biodegradable than ILs, which makes them a more sustainable option for certain applications. DESs also tend to be less corrosive and hygroscopic than ILs, which may make them easier to handle and store. They are typically less sensitive to moisture than ILs, which makes them more stable and reliable over time. In addition, DESs possesses a broad range of operational potential window and can be tailored to interact with a variety of other compounds and substances, similar to the behavior of ILs. This makes them a versatile and tunable solvent option for a wide range of applications [63]. Overall, DESs may be a viable alternative to ILs in certain applications where their inherent disadvantages may be problematic and we can see the timeline of DESs milestones in electrochemical applications in Fig. 10 . They have the potential to overcome some of the drawbacks of ILs, such as their high cost, toxicity, and poor biodegradability, making DESs a more attractive option for electrochemical applications and certain industrial processes. 6 Hole theory and exploring the effect of water on DESs’ electrochemical behaviour Because DESs have a greater viscosity than aqueous electrolytes and may have a lower conductivity as a result, their usage has been restricted in certain circumstances. While there haven't been many investigations into the flow patterns of either conventional ILs or DESs, numerous models have been devised to account for the behavior of ions in high-temperature ILs (molten salts), all of which are based on the observed phenomenon that the volume and available space within the liquid both expand upon melting. Hole theory and physical characteristics of these materials have been used to describe how the ions flow in DESs. The Fürth hole theory approach is a quantifiable method for analyzing the behavior of DESs [225]. This theory posits that when an ionic material melts, it creates empty spaces or “holes” due to fluctuations in local density. These holes are of varying sizes and locations and are constantly in flux. The radius of average-sized holes < r > is related to the surface tension of the liquid ( γ ) , as described by the Equation given below. (5) π 〈 r 2 〉 = 3.5 kT γ The Boltzmann constant, represented by k, and T is the absolute temperature. Previous research has shown that the average size of the voids in molten salts (1.5–2.5 Å) is comparable to that of the ions themselves (1–2.6 Å). This characteristic makes it effortless for small ions to occupy empty spaces, thus accounting for the low viscosity of molten salts which is akin to molecular liquids (1–5 × 10−3 Pa s). On the other hand, the surface tension of room-temperature ILs is similar to that of high-temperature fused salts, as per Equation (5), and the average size of the voids in these lower-temperature systems will be smaller. This, in conjunction with larger ion sizes, makes the mobility of ions much more challenging, which explains why the viscosity of room-temperature ILs can be as high as 101 ± 103 Pa s [226]. Although the use of hole theory to predict viscosity may not always be successful, it may be useful for designing fluids with low viscosity. The ions must be small for the liquid to flow optimally, but there must also be plenty of open spaces. By generating a liquid with low surface tension, this may be done. Because of this, alkyl imidazolium salts often exhibit their best fluidity when the alkyl groups range from C4 to C6. Although the alkyl component lowers surface tension, bigger ions move less freely. Nitrate anions, renowned for their low surface tension which can be attributed to their high charge delocalization, alongside smaller cations such as Me2NH2 +, makes combination resulting in low viscosities and high conductivities [227]. By utilizing hole theory, it is possible to craft DESs with enhanced conductivity and reduced viscosity through the incorporation of small cations or fluorinated hydrogen-bond donors [66]. When measuring the viscosity of a DES, it is believed that the fluid's distribution of cavity sizes and the probability of finding an ion-sized hole at any given moment affect its inherent viscosity. In high-temperature salts, it is more likely to find such a hole, leading to a lower viscosity. By utilizing the Stokes-Einstein formula, we can forecast the likelihood of density and the typical dimensions of unfettered spaces within these fluids and enhance their fluidity by incorporating small ions in a liquid with minimal surface tension and ample voids. This principle can also be extended to liquids that contain distinct anions [113]. Because water is so common and constituent chemicals of several DESs are hygroscopic, the water absorption by the eutectic solvents cannot be avoided [91]. While water traces in DESs are typically regarded as impurities, numerous papers have added water to their solvents on purpose in order to fine-tune their characteristics so that they can meet the needs of some desired applications. In many instances, water mixed with DESs was found to perform better. However, researchers explain the discrepancy in the literature by stating that the inclusion of water not only affects the physicochemical characteristics but may also affect the structure of DESs [228,229]. The water content in water-miscible DESs can affect various properties such as viscosity, ionic conductivity, and ESW [230]. Due to the confinement of water molecules inside the DES matrix through hydrogen bonding, adding a very small quantity of water has no effect on the ESW of DES. But the addition of water enhances the ionic conductivity of this kind of electrolyte. The reversibility and endurance of the Zn anode may be impacted if these eutectic/H2O systems change from a “water in-eutectic” to a typical “aqueous solution” regime after adding a sufficient volume of water. Some researchers examined the impact of low water content on a DES made of ChCl and urea, while others considered a range of water content levels. Research revealed that, following a period of three weeks of exposure to the environment, the DES was capable of absorbing as much as 20% of its weight in water. Few researchers investigated the impact of naturally existing water levels, up to 10% by weight, on the melting point of ChCl:urea DES and found that the melting point linearly decreased as the water content increased. When combined with 5% water, the solvent's melting point decreased from 30 °C for the dry solvent to 15 °C [231]. This important influence of water helps to explain why various studies on the same DES have produced varied outcomes. In related research, the melting pointof the same DES was also observed at various water content levels [117]. In contrast to the first study, which revealed the lowest melting point of −48.2 °C at a water content of 0.67 mol percent, the later study found a linear trend in melting point. The melting point was found to drop up to 10% water content and above this point, the melting point was found to rose. The authors hypothesized that a ternary DES composed of 1:2:6 ChCl:Urea:water may exist based on the behavior of the combination. It has been consistently found in various studies that the presence of water significantly impacts the viscosity and conductivity of DESs, while density is less affected. For example, a study observed a 22% decrease in viscosity and a 0.14% decrease in density with the addition of 0.005 mass fraction of water in ChCl:urea [232,233]. It was found that both viscosity and conductivity were significantly lower and higher, respectively, in hydrated ChCl:urea compared to the dried version, with only a 6 wt% water content. Another work also observed a significant decrease in viscosity and an increase in conductivity in ChCl:urea with the addition of 10 wt% water [234]. A reduction in viscosity and linear decrease in density was observed in NADESs made of ChCl, organic acids, sugars, and water, as the proportion of water increased, the conductivity initially rose, reaching a peak at 60%–80% water content that was 10–100 times greater than that of the pure solvent and after reaching this peak, conductivity subsequently dropped. [78]. Water plays a major role in altering the flow and electrical properties of ChCl-based DESs that have various glycols acting as HBDs, with viscosity halving after the addition of 7–10 wt% water and conductivity initially increasing with water content before decreasing after reaching a maximum at 60 wt%. The conductivity of these solvents was found to increase due to the ionic dissociation of their components, which was later decreased by dilution of electrolytes at higher water content [235]. Molecular dynamics simulations similarly revealed this non-monotonic behavior of ionic conductivity in aqueous solutions of ChCl:urea and ChCl:ethylene glycol, with values peaking at 60 percent by weight water [236]. In a recently conducted study on the impact of water on the surface tension of various mixtures, including “ChCl + water,” “ChCl + EG,” “EG + water,” and a ternary mixture of “ChCl + EG + water.” It was found that when comparing the aqueous solution of ChCl to EG, the former had stronger adsorption of choline cations due to hydrophobic interactions with water [237]. The ternary blend yielded superior equilibrium adsorption constants compared to the “ChCl + water” and “EG + water” blends, as the results indicated interactions between the elements of DESs in an adsorbed surface layer at the air/solution boundary. Meanwhile, few researchers have found that the surface tension of DL-menthol:octanoic acid and ChCl:malonic acid DESs is studied within a limited temperature range but revealed the complexity of their behavior with changing composition. Despite linear trends with temperature, the mixtures had low surface tensions and were strongly influenced by the presence of small amounts of water [173,238]. In terms of polarity, it has been found that the addition of water increased the dipolarity/polarizability and decreased the hydrogen bond basicity of ChCl:urea, ChCl:glycerol, and ChCl:EG [239]. Additionally, they discovered that ChCl:glycerol and ChCl:EG had more significant hydrogen bond interactions with the DESs components than ChCl:urea, perhaps as a result of structural variations and the interstitial accommodation of water molecules inside ChCl:urea. Water significantly impacts the properties of DESs, regardless of the amount present. It is essential to study the interactions between DESs and water, especially since binary mixtures of the two are frequently used in various applications. In fact, the presence of water can help mitigate some of the limitations of DESs, such as their relatively high viscosity, while still retaining their unique properties. However, water's strong polarity and capacity to react with hygroscopic elements of the eutectic system make it crucial to understand how water affects the intra and intermolecular bonds in the supramolecular network of DESs. Although these investigations are limited, mostly focusing on ChCl-based eutectics, and have primarily utilized techniques such as molecular dynamics simulations, Brillouin spectroscopy, neutron total scattering, and nuclear magnetic resonance. Some studies have proposed a transition from a DES to an aqueous solution of its individual components with the addition of water, while others suggest that a transition occurs from a “water-in-DES” system to a “DES-in-water” system at a certain hydration level. Water functions as an additional HBDin the lattersystem, integrating into the DES network and enhancing the hydrogen bond acceptor–donor interactions at low water content [240]. However, further, dilution weakens the interactions that typically dominate in a DES's supramolecular structure due to water's tendency to interact with the compounds forming the solvent. Chloride anions hydrate preferentially has been reported in several studies of various ChCl-based DESs, such as ChCl:urea, ChCl:glycerol, ChCl:EG, and ChCl:lactic acid [241–243]. However, the transition point at which this occurs varies, with values ranging from 15 to 51 wt% for ChCl:urea. From a recent study, it can be said that thermophysical characteristics, highly stable electrochemical windows, and capacity to inhibit corrosion even with 1% water content make it a viable electrolyte for electrochemical capacitors. Because of these features, this experiment used DESs as green electrolytes with a cell voltage of 2.2 V (Fig. 11 a) [51]. ChCl-2Urea's electrochemical window of ∼2.5 V was retained when the water content was below 6%. The presence of water reduced viscosity and improved the conductivity of ChCl-2Urea due to strong hydrogen bonding between water and urea, leading to the suppression of water decomposition and increased ionic dissociation (as supported by Fig. 11b, FTIR analysis) [244]. Although, there is a lack of research comparing the transition points of various DESs. However, it has been observed that temperature does not affect the structure of DES-water mixtures [236,245]. Further studies are needed to fully understand the impact of water on the structural arrangement of DESs and the potential for tuning these mixtures for specific applications. All aqueous mixtures of DESs likely experience this transition, though the specific water content required for the changeover may vary based on the types and ratios of hydrogen bond acceptors and donors [235]. 7 DESs in electrochemical applications DESs are a kind of solvent that has received a lot of interest recently because of their distinctive features such as good ionic conductivity, good metal-salt solubility, excellent electrochemical stability, and non-flammability and prospective uses in a variety of industries, including electrochemistry. DESs are created by combining two or more simple compounds to create a new compound with a lower melting point than any of its basic parts. Because of this, DESs are liquid at room temperature and often have greater solvating power than standard solvents. Furthermore, many DESs are derived from sustainable and renewable resources and may be readily synthesized from low-cost starting materials, making them appealing for use in electrochemical applications. In this analysis, we will examine the recent studies that have yielded promising outcomes within the realm of DESs and how these solvents may be applied in various electrochemical contexts such as serving as electrolytes in batteries and supercapacitors, partaking in electrodeposition processes, contributing to recycling efforts, acting as a medium for electrocatalytic applications among others along with environmetal applications like CO2 capture (Fig. 12 ). 7.1 Electrolytes in batteries DESs have emerged as a favorable alternative to high melting point molten salts and ILs as green electrolytes in applications such as electrolysis and batteries [246]. This is owing to their ease of synthesis in comparison to ILs, while still possessing many of the favorable characteristics of ILs. DESs possess a unique combination of properties that make them an attractive choice for use as electrolytes in energy storage devices such as batteries. Their good ionic conductivity along with their electrochemical stability, and non-flammability make them a promising alternative to other liquid electrolytes such as organic liquids, ILs, and aqueous electrolytes. In this context, this discourse will examine the most recent developments in the utilization of DESs as electrolytes for energy storage devices such as metal-based batteries. Li-Ion Batteries LIBs: the utilization of LIBs has been a significant development in technology since the 1990 s. These batteries possess several desirable attributes for energy storage, including high energy density, low self-discharge, excellent rate capability, and extended shelf-life. However, the conventional organic liquid electrolytes used in these batteries are highly flammable and volatile, leading to significant safety concerns such as the possibility of fire or explosion in abusive conditions like overheating, overcharging, or impact [247]. As a result, the development of low-cost electrolytes with low flammability, high ionic conductivity, and excellent thermal stability is imperative. In this regard, LiTFSI, and acetamide-based electrolytes show promise for LIBs, due to their remarkable thermal stability, strong ion conductivity, a wide range of electrochemical stability, and low viscosity even at room temperature. This is explained by the Li+ ions' efficient coordination with the C=O group in the structure of acetamide (or urea). These electrolytes do not seem to interact with the electrode surface in a Li-ion battery, according to a study that successfully evaluated the cycling performance of LiFePO4. Furthermore, with an efficiency of more than 99%, the discharge capacity ratio at 80 °C is only 1% after 20 cycles of the original discharge capacity [175]. Taking it forward in another study, recently DES was made from a mixture of 2,2,2-trifluoroacetamide (TFA) and LiTFSI. The DESs were evaluated and showed good results for thermal stability (∼5.2 V vs. Li+/Li), ionic conductivity (1.5 mS cm−1 at 30 °C), and electrochemical properties. Results showed that DESs have favorable properties and can be used in Li-ion batteries when diluted with a small amount of ethylene carbonate (EC). The results of the tests on the cathode made of LiMn2O4 and the Li anode indicate that the electrolyte solution of LiTFSI: TFA in a 4:1 ratio with an additional 10% of EC (DES) yielded the best performance with a capacity of 102 mA h g−1 and maintained a steady cycle behavior for 50 cycles [248]. Considering the perspective of aqueous electrolytes, conventional aqueous electrolytes have narrow potential windows of less than 1.5 V. Recently, a novel electrolyte system (DES) made of water, lithium perchlorate, and methylsulfonylmethane has been created as a safe, cost-efficient alternative. When the molar ratio is 1.8:1:z, the lithium-ion in this system may interact with the oxygen atom in the S═Odouble bond, perchlorate, and water molecule to produce a liquid electrolyte at room temperature (where z is greater than 0.3). This DES electrolyte has an impressive electrochemical stability window of 3.5 V, which enables high energy density and capacity retention in the LiMn2O4/Li4Ti5O12 aqueous lithium-ion battery [249]. Many other combinations of DESs and additives are tried and applied and show good results. EC-LiTFSI based DES shows safe results up to 80 °C for Li-ion batteries [250]. ZnCl2:acetamide:H2O (1:3:1) based DES with Coulombic efficiency ∼98% and over 1000 cycles, a battery was constructed using a phenazine cathode and Zn anode, which demonstrated exceptional stability and performance by cycling stably over 10,000 cycles while maintaining a high capacity retention of 85.7% [251]. The LiPF6/EG:ChCl electrolyte-based DES with a concentration of 0.5 M has proven to be highly conductive, with an ionic conductivity of 7.95 mS cm−1 at room temperature, making it a promising and cost-effective option as a green electrolyte [252]. While liquid DESs are often considered environment-friendly solvents for use in LIBs, encapsulating them within a polymer matrix could be an attractive solution for developing leak-free and nonhazardous LIBs. In this regard, recently a new class of gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), consisting of UV-cured acrylic polymers and a LiTFSI/NMAc DES which are safe and high-performing was introduced [175]. These eutectic GPEs have better electrochemical stability than liquid DESs, although their rate performance still requires improvement. It is important to note that eutectic GPEs are less flammable than liquid DESs, thanks to the presence of a polymer matrix [253]. Li metal has a high specific capacity of 3860 mA h g−1 and a low electrode potential of −3.04 V compared to the standard hydrogen electrode, making it an attractive anode material for Li batteries. However, the practical use of Li metal as an anode is limited due to issues with unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and uncontrollable dendritic growth, which can result in low Coulombic efficiency, capacity fading, and safety concerns [254]. To address these issues, researchers have designed eutectic electrolytes, such as succinonitrile (SN)-based dual-anion DES, which can prevent Li dendrite growth and improve battery performance. The SN-based DES electrolyte exhibits a good ionic conductivity of 2.86 mS cm−1, a large Li transfer number of 0.44 at 25 °C, good interfacial compatibility with Li metal, and is non-flammable with negligible weight loss at 150 °C, making it a safe and effective alternative to conventional carbonate electrolytes [255]. To prevent interfacial resistance caused by side reactions between Li and free HBD molecules, a stable SEI can be formed. Recently, researchers developed a DES-based polymer (DSP) electrolyte using LiTFSI and NMAc eutectic mixture with FEC as an additive [256]. The addition of FEC improved the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability of the polymer electrolyte while promoting stable interfaces at both the anode and cathode. The self-healing polymer matrix regulated Li-ion flux and suppressed Mn2+ dissolution from Li transition metal oxide cathode. The DSP electrolyte enabled uniform Li deposition and high plating/stripping CEs, with a reversible capacity of 99.5 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles and capacity retention of 86.1%. In contrast, LMO||DES electrolyte||Li cell suffered from rapid capacity fading and failure after only 80 cycles. Zinc batteries: zinc batteries have garnered renewed interest in recent years due to their large reserves, environmental friendliness, and intrinsic safety, making them highly desirable for large-scale energy storage systems. Unlike alkali metals, zinc metal is insensitive to oxygen and humidity, which broadens the availability of electrolytes and lowers processing costs. Additionally, zinc metal exhibits a high volumetric capacity of 5855 A h L−1, which is superior to its counterparts such as lithium (2061 A h L−1), calcium (2072 A h L−1), and magnesium (3833 A h L−1). However, the suboptimal cyclic efficiency resulting from uncontrolled dendrites and notorious side reactions occurring at the Zn-electrolyte interface, especially for aqueous electrolytes, has hindered the development and practical application of rechargeable zinc batteries [257]. There are some reports suggesting the use of polar-aprotic electrolytes such as acetonitrile/Zn salt mixtures for zinc batteries for improved performance, but acetonitrile is flammable, toxic, and volatile, reducing the overall stability of the battery. ILs seem to be a good choice, but their high cost and sensitivity to moisture make them less practical for real-world applications. Recently, DESs have been widely studied as electrolytes for zinc batteries because of their good stability in the air and moisture, low toxicity, low cost, and strong water-miscibility. For instance, recently, a biocompatible, stable, and low-cost ChCl/ZnCl2/urea DES electrolyte was reported with no dendrites were found on the surface of zinc metal, suggesting highly reversible plating/stripping behavior. The Zn battery showed a slow fading rate of 0.7% per cycle when delta-type manganese oxide (δ-MnO2) was used as a cathode material. Although the Coulombic efficiencies of ∼90% at a current density of 100 mA g−1 need to be further improved, the above result indicates the great potential of the ChCl/ZnCl2/urea electrolyte for zinc batteries [258]. Currently, the application of ZnCl2-based DES electrolytes is still hindered by their corrosivity toward common battery components, especially at high operating voltages. In another study, a stable and effective aqueous electrolyte by incorporating a small amount of water (∼6wt%) into a urea-based DES was fabricated. The addition of water led to the formation of homogeneous and clear solutions (described as LZ-DES/nH2O; molar ratio: n = 0.5, 1, and 2). Among the LZ-DES/nH2O electrolytes, the LZ-DES/2H2O had a significantly reduced viscosity (139 mPa s) and an enhanced conductivity (1.85 mS cm−1) at 30 °C. The in situ optical microscopy observation revealed that gas bubbling is serious when zinc was deposited in a 0.5 M LiTFSI + 0.5 M Zn(TFSI)2 aqueous electrolyte, resulting in a non-uniform deposition. In contrast, the LZ-DES/nH2O is more compatible with zinc metal, and no H2 evolution was observed during the operando testing of zinc||zinc symmetric cells. The smooth plating/stripping curves confirm the good stability of zinc||zinc symmetric cells with the LZ-DES/2H2O electrolyte. The zinc||LiMnO2 battery showed excellent cyclic performance with a capacity retention of 90 [259]. In the context of rechargeable batteries, the stability of the SEI is a critical factor that affects the battery's cycle life. Recently, a group of researchers introduced an innovative approach to construct a zinc fluoride-rich organic/inorganic hybrid SEI on zinc anode using a Zn(TFSI)2/Ace eutectic electrolyte. The electrolyte contains TFSI−, which coordinates directly with Zn2+ in the form of anion-containing Zn complexes. This coordination leads to the preferential reductive decomposition of TFSI− before Zn deposition, which results in the in-situ formation of a fluoride-rich SEI layer on the Zn surface. This SEI layer enables high cyclic efficiency values and uniform Zn plating/stripping at the areal capacity of > 2.5 mA h cm−2, due to the excellent stable SEI on Zn anode without competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The fluoride-rich SEI layer also remains stable when the battery is operated in a 1 M Zn(TFSI)2 aqueous electrolyte, which is far superior to the pristine Zn without SEI protection. The cyclic stability of Zn||V2O5 cells using DES electrolyte (Zn(TFSI)2:Ace = 1:7, molar ratio) outperforms the aqueous counterparts. However, Zn(TFSI)2-based DESs are expensive due to the high cost of Zn(TFSI)2 [260]. Therefore, expanding the types of salts and HBDs would be of great interest to further increase the overall features of DES-based electrolytes. Aluminum (Al) Batteries: The development of Al-based batteries has gained attention as a promising alternative to current LIBs due to their three-electron redox properties, low reduction potential, stability in the metallic state, and high natural abundance. However, the use of nonflammable electrolytes with low toxicity is crucial to minimize safety hazards and environmental impact. Previously constructed Al battery with chloroaluminate-based ILs showed high energy density but had high sensitivity to moisture and relatively expensive, for example an ultrafast rechargeable Al battery was developed using chloroaluminate-based ILs with a high energy density of 40 Wh kg−1 and over 7500 cycles, but still had the same limitations. To address these limitations, recently the use of a DES prepared from a mixture of AlCl3 and urea in a 1.3:1 molar ratio for RT Al − graphite battery was explored. This battery exhibited two discharge voltage plateaus and yielded a specific cathode capacity of ∼73 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1 with high cyclic efficiency over a large range of charge–discharge rates and stability over ∼150–200 cycles [261]. However, despite the promising results, the DES electrolyte consisting of AlCl3 and urea still needs to be improved due to its high viscosity and low conductivity/ionicity. The same group of researchers also investigated the ionic conductivity and viscosity of AlCl3/urea derivatives, achieving a significantly lower viscosity but not a remarkable increase in conductivity as expected. Therefore, DESs with high ionic conductivity for Al-ion batteries need to be further explored. These chloroaluminate-based DESs further extended as a low-cost electrolyte for a reversible Al-S and Al-Se batteries. A DES electrolyte composed of AlCl3 and acetamide allows the Al-S battery to have an initial capacity of over 1500 mA h g−1 and maintain good performance at high discharge rates, likely due to the presence of AlCl4 −, Al2Cl7 − and [AlCl2·(acetamide)2]+ ions as determined by spectroscopic analysis [262]. Similarly, for Al-Se battery with Se nanowires on Carbon Cloth as cathode and Al foil as anode, the thiourea-AlCl3 electrolyte has an exceptional specific capacity of 260 mA h g−1 and a prolonged cycle life of 100 cycles. Additionally, at 100 mA g−1, this electrolyte displays a remarkably high Coulombic efficiency of around 93% [263]. The use of Al–air batteries, which have a high specific energy density, is becoming increasingly popular. A recent development in this area is the use of DESs as a solid electrolyte. DESs have been found to be effective at removing byproducts, such as Al2O3 and Al(OH)3, which can accumulate at both the anode and cathode. DESsare less sensitive to air and water than ILs, which is one advantage of utilizing DESs. One example of a DES-based solid electrolyte for rechargeable Al–air batteries was synthesized by mixing AlCl3, urea, carboxymethyl cellulose, and glycerin, while titanium nitride was used as the cathode. The resulting Al–air battery had an initial capacity of 35.8 mA h g−1 and capacity retention of 97.8% for 50 cycles [264]. Other AlCl3-based DESs have also been developed for Al–air batteries. For example, a full-cell using AlCl3/Ace (1:1.5) electrolyte displayed a current and energy efficiency of 84% and 56% at 100 µA cm−2 for 3 h, respectively [265]. Compared to IL electrolytes, such as EMIMCl, DES electrolytes have been found to enable Al–air batteries to show better stability and higher voltage output. However, there is still room for improvement in the development of new salts and HBDs to further enhance the ionic conductivity and extend the ESW. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in developing rechargeable magnesium-metal batteries. Magnesium is an abundant and low-cost element, which makes it an attractive candidate for battery applications. However, one of the major challenges in developing magnesium batteries is finding suitable electrolytes that can offer high conductivity, thermal and electrochemical stability, and safety. Recently, a new category of electrolytes that are suitable for use in rechargeable magnesium batteries was studied, consisting of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (EMIC) combined with either Mg(ClO4)2 or Mg(CF3SO3)2, these electrolytes belong to DES class. By optimizing the molar ratio to 1:0.16 for EMIC-Mg(ClO4)2 and 1:0.14 for EMIC-Mg(CF3SO3)2, high conductivity levels of 2.8 and 2.4 mS cm−1, respectively, were obtained at 25 °C. Also, an anodic stability of approximately 3.0 V vs. Mg/Mg2+ was observed when using graphite as a working electrode. The Graphite|DES|Mg cells delivered a remarkable stability of around 40 mA h g−1 over 50 cycles [266]. Studies on DESs-based electrolytes for Mg batteries is still preliminary, the results suggest that DES-based electrolytes could be a promising alternative to traditional solvent-based electrolytes for magnesium batteries. These findings demonstrate that DESs are highly advantageous electrolytes owing to their exceptional thermal stability and safety features, as well as their superionic characteristics at high temperatures. 7.2 Electrolytes in supercapacitors Supercapacitors, also known as ultracapacitors, are energy storage devices that store electrical energy using the principle of electrostatic charge separation. They have much higher capacitance values than traditional capacitors, making them useful for various applications. Their energy density is substantial, with extended operational longevity and versatility across a broad range of temperatures, even in extreme conditions [267–269]. DESs are being increasingly researched as a potential electrolyte for supercapacitors due to their potential for being a green, safe, and low-cost alternative to the commonly used liquid electrolytes, such as aqueous solutions, organic solutions, and ILs [206]. Since water decomposition limits the voltage window of the aqueous electrolyte, organic liquids are often very flammable and poisonous, and ILs are expensive. DES electrolytes have been found to have strong thermal stability and good ionic conductivity, allowing supercapacitors to operate at high temperatures, which is desirable for specialized applications such as military and aerospace [270,271]. In this regard, study on a new DES electrolyte based on sodium nitrate and NMAc have shown promising findings, such as a high capacitance of 100 F g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1 and capacity retention of 80% for 1000 charge–discharge cycles [272]. A less costly and safer DES composed of ChCl and EG was developed in a separate experiment. The stability of the ChCl/EG DESs with different molar ratios (1:1, 1:2, and 1:4) was investigated by comparing the adsorption energies [273]. According to the investigation, DESChCl:EG(1:2) has the most steady value, showing the adsorption energy value of 4.42 eV. Additionally, from ambient temperature to 115 °C, ChCl/EG DES exhibits a rise in ionic conductivity while the viscosity exhibits the reverse trend. The high thermal stability of the DESs resulting from the intramolecular hydrogen bonds allows the ChCl/EG DES to function correctly throughout a broad temperature range of −40 to 115 °C. Recently few researchers improved the ionic conductivity of a typical DES (LiClO4, acetamide) electrolyte by adding cosolvents of water and acetonitrile. With this addition, the problems of high viscosity and poor conductivity are addressed, and the anti-freeze and wettability qualities are also enhanced [274]. These hybrid DES demonstrates ideal properties when the acetonitrile to water ratio is 4.4:1, including a broad ESW of 2.55 V, high conductivity of 15.6 mS cm−1, and low viscosity of 5.82 mPa s. Water molecules are highly bonded to Li+ ions, as shown by spectroscopic studies, which contributes to the broad ESW. Using this hybrid DES electrolyte and hydrogel of 1 T-MoS2 reduced graphene oxide (rGO) hydrogel electrode, the researchers achieved a maximum energy density of 31.2 Wh kg−1 at a power density of 1164 W kg−1 and demonstrated exceptional cyclic stability of 20,000 cycles in symmetric supercapacitors [275]. Recently, a study discovered that the ratio of components, notably ChCl, EG, and H2O, significantly affects the solvent's structure and performance in supercapacitors. The 1:2:2 ratio was found to be the most efficient ratio, producing a stable structure with a high voltage window of 2.4 V, a broad −40 to 80 °C temperature range, a specific capacity of 202 F g−1, an energy density of 40.3 Wh kg−1, and high cyclability of 98.51% after 10,000 cycles [276]. Newly introduced, an eco-friendly method for creating a unique material known as sulfur and nitrogen co-functionalized reduced graphene oxide (SN-rGO), this process boasts impressive capabilities. SN-rGO boasts an astounding specific capacitance of 509 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1, resulting in incredible energy and power densities of 57.3 Wh kg−1 and 1804.7 W kg−1, respectively [277]. In order to create supercapacitors with enhanced capabilities, researchers have turned to gels made up of DES and a polymer matrix. These gels act as quasi-solid-state electrolytes, allowing for improved performance. The environmentally friendly poly(vinyl alcohol)/Ace/LiClO4 (PAL) gel electrolyte is one illustration of this, and it has a high ionic conductivity of around 12 mS cm−1. High-voltage wearable asymmetric supercapacitors (HVWASCs) with an anodic voltage of 4.2 V were created using this gel, and they have outstanding energy density and power capabilities [278]. Another study utilized a double network ion gel composed of a conductive DES, acrylamide, cellulose fiber, ChCl, urea, and glycerol. This ion gel was used in the creation of supercapacitors with high specific capacitance (76.6 F g−1 at 1.0 A g−1) and energy density (10.64 Wh kg−1), thanks to its high ionic conductivity of (0.58 mS cm−1) and wide operating voltage window [279]. Researchers have found a novel method for increasing the energy density of carbon-based supercapacitors by employing a ternary DES made of urea and lithium perchlorate trihydrate. Eutectogels (ETGs) may be made using this solution, which has a freezing point below −85.6 °C, in a free radical polymerization procedure. The most often used electrolyte for making ETGs is LiTFSI-NMAc due to its strong ionic conductivity and low viscosity [280]. These ETGs can maintain their flexibility at very low temperatures (−40 °C) and have a strong ionic conductivity at normal temperatures. The resultant supercapacitors have an excellent cyclic longevity of around 105% capacitance retention after 10,000 cycles, a steady voltage window of 0–2.0 V, and an energy density of 10.76 Wh kg−1. These supercapacitors also retain a modest degree of bendability while functioning over a broad temperature range (−40 to 60 °C). The supercapacitor's remarkable potential in this sector was shown by the fact that it could continue to charge and power a mini-fan for around 60 s even after being damaged [281]. Taking a different aspect into consideration, a new study has uncovered a revolutionary new solution for the energy storage industry, Reline DES electrolytes. These low-cost, eco-friendly electrolytes have proven to be game changers in the field of supercapacitors. They are unmatched by any other electrolytes in terms of long-term stability owing to their anti-corrosive nature, in addition to providing a high working voltage window and strong capacitive performance. Reline DES and its water mixtures have shown to be the ultimate corrosion resistance solution for steel current collectors compared to the likes of other electrolytes such as 1 M KOH, 1 M H2SO4, and 1 M Li2SO4. The Tafel plots (Fig. 13 a) by extrapolating the linear segments of the cathodic and anodic regions and the technique of cyclic potentiodynamic polarization (Fig. 13b), commonly employed to investigate localized material corrosion, including pitting were used to determine the corrosion properties in three different electrolytes for stainless steel 316L disc electrodes. The study has also demonstrated that Reline DES-based systems do not show remarkable deterioration during floating at 2.2 V, this is a clear indication of its superior anti-corrosive performance. The study suggests that using Reline DES electrolytes in supercapacitors is an important step towards low-cost, environmentally friendly, high-energy, and safe energy storage systems [282]. When it comes to supercapacitors, metal-based eutectic electrolytes are a game-changer. In comparison to quaternary ammonium salt-based alternatives, eutectic electrolytes have a substantially lower viscosity and better ionic conductivity. Carbon-based supercapacitors may obtain a high specific capacity and cycling performance even at high temperatures by utilizing eutectic electrolytes such LiTFSI-acetamide, LiTFSI-NMAc, and NaNO3-NMAc [272,283,284]. But the possibilities don't stop there-using eutectic electrolytes containing ILs further enhances the potential window of supercapacitors. A supercapacitor made from the eutectic IL combination of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)-imide and 1-propyl-3-methylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)-imide, for instance, can achieve a cell voltage of 3.5 V throughout a large temperature range, from minus 70 to 80 °C [285]. In a different research, DESs based on sodium and lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imides were mixed with formamide and N-methylacetamide, which are utilized as the electrolytes for activated carbonsupercapacitors (ACSs) at 25 °C. High electrochemical window (E > 2.5 V), great temperature stability (150 °C), strong ionic conductivity (3–4 mS cm−1), and low viscosity are all characteristics of these designed DESs (11.3 mPa s). Through the use of cyclic voltammetry, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, and galvanostatic charge/discharge tests, the performance of the ACSs was assessed. The results revealed a 140 F g−1 capacity with 8% retention after 200 h of floating [159]. In another study, a new DES utilizes a combination of tetraethylammonium bromide (TEAB) or tetraethylammonium chloride (TEAC) as an HBA and ethylene glycol (EG) as an HBD. The benefits of these DES electrolytes over conventional aqueous electrolytes include a larger electrochemical stable window (up to 3.03 V), a wider working temperature range (−40 to 115 °C), strong ionic conductivity (8.70 mS cm−1 at 25 °C), and low viscosity (18.13 mPa s at 25 °C). In addition, utilizing DES electrolytes results in improved cycling stability with 92.8% capacity retention at 1 Ag+ after 10,000 cycles, a greater energy density at 32.2 Wh kg−1, and a rise in cell voltage (2.4 V at −40 °C) [286]. In another study, researchers pioneered the utilization of DESs to create CuCo2O4 (CCO) nanomaterials for supercapacitor applications. The optimized CCO electrode was found to exhibit extraordinary supercapacitive abilities, boasting a specific capacity of 421 mA h g−1 at 10 mV s−1 and exceptional performance in both GCD and cycling stability tests [287]. The excellent electrochemical stability, low toxicity, strong thermal stability, low volatility, and a larger working temperature range of DESs make them useful as electrolytes for diverse batteries. The ionic conductivity of DES electrolytes is around one order lower than that of traditional liquid electrolytes, which has a detrimental effect on rate performance and presently restricts their application in conventional energy storage systems. Researchers are striving to create DES electrolytes with strong ionic conductivity to get over this restriction. To increase the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability of DESs against lithium metal, one method is to add a low-viscosity organic solvent, such as fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) [256]. Additionally, to improve ionic conductivity by lowering viscosity, research into novel salts and HBDs for DESs is crucial. Avoiding side reactions between the DES electrolyte and the alkali metal anodes is another crucial factor. One potential solution to mitigate the clash between the electrolyte utilized in DES and highly reactive alkali metals is to encase the DES liquid within a polymer matrix, thereby limiting the amount of unbound HBD molecules present [255,288]. 7.3 Electrodeposition of metals and alloys DESs have been found to be suitable for electrodeposition, a widely used surface finishing technique that involves forming a solid metal coating on an electrode surface from metal cations dispersed in the electrolyte. The electrodeposition process can enhance properties such as hardness, corrosion and wear resistance, abrasion resistance, brightness, magnetism, and electrocatalysis [289,290]. While aqueous solutions are typically used for electrodeposition, they have limitations such as gas evolution, hydrogen embrittlement, and the formation of insoluble oxides and hydroxides that impede thick metallic coatings. Additionally, traditional aqueous solutions often contain toxic components and have low current efficiency [291]. In contrast, DESs have a wider potential window, lack water, have relatively high conductivity, are relatively low cost, and are biodegradable. They can be used to electrodeposit metals that have Nernst potentials well below the water decomposition potential, such as titanium, aluminum, and tungsten, which have industrial applications such as corrosion resistance [36]. Using electrodeposition from DESs may bypass legal limitations associated with the toxicity of carcinogenic liquid precursors and expenses for disposal. The shape and adherence of developing metal coatings are influenced by the current density, the ingredients of the DES, and the addition of other substances [292]. Recently, the use of cobalt-phosphorous (Co-P) coatings was investigatedas a substitute for hard chromium due to its exceptional corrosion protective capabilities. DES, which is based on ChCl and ethylene glycol (Ethaline), was used to create the Co-P coatings. Saccharin (SA) was added as an addition, the addition of SA caused the substrate to develop closely-grown, P-rich Co-P coatings with smaller grains and smoother surfaces. The optimum Co-P coating displayed exceptional anti-corrosion and barrier protection properties for mild steel in corrosive NaCl solution, outperforming its competition up to 10 times better. This work highlights the crucial role additives play in influencing the structure and composition of deposited Co-P coatings in ethaline-based DES in addition to providing a unique technique for producing high-performance coating materials for anti-corrosion applications [293]. Ni-Mo alloy coatings were effectively plated recently onto a copper base material, using a non-aqueous plating bath based on a DES made of ChCland propylene glycol (1:2). At all of the investigated deposition potentials, homogenous, adherent coatings with nodular morphology were formed. Deposition current density and Mo content rose when the potential varied, but further shifts in the potential resulted in a drop in Mo content and a deterioration in coating quality. The coating with the highest degree of uniformity was created at −0.6 V and measured around 660 nm in thickness, with a maximum crystallite size of 10 nm. The coatings have minimal corrosion currents and high corrosion resistance. The coatings that were coated at −0.5, −0.6, and −0.7 V had the greatest charge transfer resistances [294]. Overall, while the use of DESs for electrodeposition is still in its early stages, it shows great potential as an alternative to traditional aqueous solutions. However, further research is needed to address the instability of DES baths during the electrodeposition process and to make the process economically competitive. 7.4 Redox flow batteries The potential success of utilizing DESs in RFBs can be determined by evaluating both their economic and environmental effects. Recent studies have emphasized producing extremely concentrated eutectic electrolytes and examining the relationship between molecular interactions, concentration, and material redox-activity [295,296]. We also investigated the possible use of these electrolytes in high-energy–density RFBs. It makes sense in this procedure to compare the performance of recently reported DESs in RFBs to that of the commercially manufactured vanadium RFB (VRFB). Metal and organic-based DESs were made by combining metal and organic electroactive materials with the proper inorganic or organic substances, such as quaternary ammonium salts or HBD, in order to generate large concentrations of active species [297]. AlCl3, ZnCl2, and FeCl3.6H2O DESs, which can readily produce concentrations of active species exceeding 2 M, are now the most researched examples of high-concentration DESs [151]. The redox reactions in these DESs rely on the coordination environment and valence state of the metal centers as well as the metal chloride used as a eutectic constituent and redox species. A rechargeable redox battery with a Li anode and a Fe-based catholyte that contains a eutectic combination of FeCl3·6H2O and urea has been described [298]. This battery demonstrated long-term stability and an active species concentration of5.4 Munder ambient conditions. This Li-Fe hybrid battery showed a high potential of 3.4 V and a gravimetric energy density of 330 Wh kg−1, which is equivalent to modern Li-ion batteries. The conversion of two iron complex species during charging and discharging is how the reversible redox processes in this Fe-based DES were accomplished. To boost the molar portion of active species in organic-based electrolytes as a substitute, the use of eutectic principles is gaining popularity [299]. The efficacy of this strategy has been proven in highly concentrated organic redox species. At room temperature, LiTFSI was coupled with 4-methoxy-2,2,6,6-tetra-methypiperidine 1-oxyl (MT) to get an orange catholyte with a high concentration of more than 2 M [300]. The MT-TFSI and MT-Li+ relationships may be broken up by the presence of a little quantity of water, enabling ions to flow about more freely. As a result, as the water molar ratio rose, so did the usage of MT active species and discharge voltage. DESs show promise for RFBs due to their high solubility of metal oxides containing vanadium, chromium, iron, and zinc, particularly in DESs based on urea or malonic acid. Adding iodine as an electrocatalyst further enhances solubility and improves energy densities of RFBs [153]. Additionally, DESs have cost-effective production and high heterogeneous rate constants for various metallic species, and their versatility is increased by the ability to make them from different salts and HBDs. 7.5 Dye-sensitized solar cells Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), a particular kind of photoelectrochemical cell that has garnered attention as a workable renewable energy option since its introduction in 1991, have shown promising results in the field of power generation. DSSCs depend on the electrical potential difference between the semiconductor (often TiO2) and the redox potential of the electrolyte used to separate the semiconductor from the opposing electrode, as opposed to other types of photoelectrochemical cells (Fig. 14 ) [301]. According to previous findings, an electrolyte containing 0.5 M tetrapropylammonium iodide, 0.04 M iodine, and 80% v/v ethylene carbonate and acetonitrile may obtain a conversion efficiency of 7.9% [302]. Although ACN-based electrolytes have promising properties for the development of DSSCs, concerns about their hazardous nature and high volatility have hindered their widespread use in large-scale applications. To address this issue, quasi-solid electrolytes based on ILs in a gel-like form with excellent photovoltaic performance and long-term stability have been proposed. Additionally, DESs have been suggested as a potential alternative for improving liquid electrolytes within the framework of green chemistry. DESs have low toxicity, are biodegradable, thermally stable, non-flammable, have low vapor pressure, and are cost-effective. These characteristics make DESs an ideal platform for developing DSSCs sustainably [303]. Glycerol and choline iodide, in a 1:3 molar ratio, have recently been studied as a DES (deep eutectic solvent) electrolyte in a non-aqueous DSSC [304]. Compared to a DSSC utilizing a traditional IL electrolyte, an increase in the diffusion coefficient of the I3− redox-active species (8.7 × 10−7 cm2 s−1) and ionic conductivity of 5.3 mS cm−1 was seen despite the relatively high water content of 15 wt%. However, compared to a DSSC employing an IL electrolyte, the DSSC conversion was lower [304,305]. The effectiveness of PC and TBAI-based DES (PC/TBAI-DES) as a novel electrolyte solvent for DSSCs was recently assessed in research. The electrolyte composition of 0.1 M iodine and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium iodide (EmimI) in a binary combination of PC/TBAI-DES and acetonitrile (AN) with a volume ratio of 80:20 was found to provide the best electrolyte conditions. These electrolyte-based DSSCs acquired a noteworthy conversion efficiency of 10.04% (the open-circuit voltage is 0.78 V, the fill factor is 0.58, and the short-circuit current density is 21.94 mA cm2). In order to investigate the molecular arrangement of the PC/TBAI-DES solution close to the titanium dioxide and platinum solid surfaces acting as electrodes of DSSCs and to ascertain the interaction parameters between the TBAI ion pair and PC molecule, molecular dynamics simulations, and density functional theory were also used [306]. Recent research has looked at how K+ and Emim+ counterions affect the functioning of DSSCs in DES-based electrolytes. The study's results showed how much the DSSC's efficiency is boosted by adding KI salt to the electrolyte solution based on photovoltaic and electrochemical properties [307]. The performance of DSSCs was improved by examining photocurrent density–voltage charts; this led to an efficiency of 9.26% when utilizing an electrolyte solution including LiI, EmimI, and I2, as well as a 60:40 v/v ratio of CholCl/EG DES and MeCN. Both the efficiency and the TBP addition to the electrolyte resulted in high values of 9.48%. According to an analysis of mean square displacement curves, the diffusion coefficients (10−11 m2 s−1), rose in the following order: Li+ (0.82), Emim+ (1.01), Chol+ (1.15), Cl− (1.29), I− (1.74), EG (5.99), and MeCN (102.92) [308]. Understanding the interfacial structure of DESs in confined channels and the impact of surfactant additions for aqueous DES electrolytes in DSSCs are two further areas of research on DESs as prospective electrolytes in DSSCs that might result in better DES electrolyte design [309]. 7.6 Electropolishing of metals The practice of electropolishing, which involves the controlled dissolution of a metal surface to improve its surface smoothness and optical reflectivity, has been a topic of investigation since it was first patented in 1930 [310,311]. This technique not only increases resistance to corrosion and decreases wear but also enhances lubrication in engines, thereby addressing a major cause of mechanical failure. The majority of current commercial electropolishing processes utilize aqueous solutions of phosphoric and sulfuric acids, in addition to various additives such as CrO3. However, these methods have several drawbacks, including the use of highly corrosive and toxic solutions and low current efficiency due to excessive gas evolution during the process. An alternative method, electropolishing with DESs, offers several advantages over traditional aqueous processes. Firstly, gas evolution is minimal, resulting in higher current efficiencies. Secondly, In contrast to typical electropolishing electrolytes which rely on highly acidic and hazardous solutions, DESs offer significant advantages in terms of environmental safety and low levels of corrosiveness. Additionally, DESs enable electrochemical polishing to be carried out at room temperature. Given these benefits, it appears that DESs hold tremendous potential as a medium for conducting electrochemical polishing. Historically, electropolishing has been primarily used on stainless steels, but it has also been applied to other materials such as titanium, Ni and Co alloys, and aluminum with the use of DESs. A study examines the effects of electropolishing aluminum in Ethaline, a eutectic mixture of ChCl and ethylene glycol. The results showed that electropolishing at higher electrode potentials resulted in a faster dissolution rate and improved surface morphology, with no anodization of the aluminum observed (Fig. 15 ). The electropolishing also led to an increase in microhardness, corrosion resistance, and surface hydrophobicity of the aluminum. Overall, Ethaline was found to be a promising medium for electropolishing aluminum [312]. Another study explores the electrochemical polishing of Ti-based alloy using Ethaline, a low-impact eutectic solvent. The electropolishing process was carried out at 25 °C for 30–40 min in a potentiostatic mode (E at +3.0 V and +4.0 V). The results showed that surface smoothing and reduction of surface roughness was achieved through the removal of surface roughness. This process can be used for the treatment of various biomedical items with success [313]. Recently, a study shows that cobalt and nickel can be effectively polished through electropolishing at 20 °C in ChCl:EG (1:2) solution. This was confirmed through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, where the formation of a film on the electrode surface and the diffusional Warburg impedance was observed. This highlights the crucial role of mass transportation through the film, specifically the diffusion of solvated oxidized metals, in the electropolishing process. This indicates that polishing kinetics is essential. The results were comparable to those seen in DES with stainless steel [314]. It is important to mention that commercial aluminum alloys consist of various alloying elements such as copper, magnesium, manganese, silicon, zinc, etc. These elements can significantly impact both the electrochemical polishing process using DESs-based electrolytes and the characteristics of the treated surface. To gain a better understanding of this matter, additional research is necessary. 7.7 Synthesis of electrode materials and nanomaterials DESsare excellent building blocks for developing sophisticated functional materials because of their good ionic conductivity, low surface tension,and high dielectric constant. Additionally, DESs offer several advantages over traditional solvents, which can be summarized as follows: Firstly, their non-conventional solvent effect can be used to influence the growth of materials. Secondly, preparing DESs is straightforward, scalable, and cost-effective. Thirdly, DESs are environmentally friendly as they are biodegradable, renewable, and non-toxic. Lastly, their chemical inertness with water makes them easy to store. DESs maybe investigated as reactants or precursors in the synthesis of nanomaterials. In the past, DESs have been used as precursors to create a variety of carbon materials. The ability of DESs to exfoliate multilayer nanomaterials has also attracted interest. It is crucial to keep in mind that research on employing DESs to create novel materials is still in its infancy, especially with respect to applications involving energy storage. The discussion in this part will emphasize DES-based functional material synthesis for energy storage. Carbonaceous materials are frequently prepared using DESsas precursors. The first attempts to synthesize carbonaceous compounds using DESs were made by Francisco del Monte and colleagues [315]. In 2010, they produced a resorcinol–formaldehyde gel using ChCl:EG (1:2) as a DES. When compared to carbon obtained from pure water, the carbon obtained using this approach had a substantially larger specific surface area (170 m2 g−1). The creation ofporous carbon monoliths with a carbon conversion of around 80% is made possible by the use of DESs as precursors in the formaldehyde polycondensation and subsequent carbonization processes. The porous/CNT composites created with this technique also have a large specific surface area and good electrical conductivity, maintaining 75% of their original capacitance at high current densities (765 mA cm−2) [316]. DESs have been utilized in the production of various intrinsic nitrogen-doped carbons through direct carbonization. One prominent example is the use of a particularly designed DES to produce N/O self-doped hollow carbon nanorods (HCNs) with micro/mesoporous walls [317]. Urea, 2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-benzoquinone, and ZnCl2 produced this DES by hydrogen-bond interactions, with ZnCl2 acting as both a hydrogen-bond acceptor and a dehydrating agent to encourage condensation. ZnCl2 also served as a precursor material during carbonization by creating a ZnO template, which led to the creation of porous HCNs. These HCNs were used to create symmetric supercapacitors, which had a high energy density of 116.5 W h kg−1 and a power density of 472 W kg−1 [318]. Due to their potential capabilities in the creation of electroanalytical platforms, graphene, and DESs have been coupled. A centimeter-scale graphene monolayer was transferred onto insulating SiO2/Si substrates in the DES ethaline in recent research [319]. The electrochemical behavior of the graphene/DES system was also described. The research also examined the electrochemical performances of metal and metalloid modifications of graphene in the DES. The results demonstrated that although the behavior of graphene in ethaline is comparable to that of glassy carbon or highly ordered pyrolytic graphite, other characteristics were distinct because graphene is a two-dimensional material. The possibility of employing NADESsfor altering carbon paste electrodes has recently come to light in investigations [320]. When recording cyclic voltammograms of potassium ferrocyanide with the NADES-modified carbon paste electrode, NADESs improved the conductivity and charge transfer rate. The oxidation of dopamine and ascorbic acid using a reline-modified carbon paste electrode also showed improved performance. Additionally, the capacity of DESs to functionalize carbon nanotubes (Fig. 16 a–c) was explored, the carbon nanotubes' surface area increased and new functional groups formed on their surfaces without compromising their structural integrity [321,322]. Recent research employing conventional molecular dynamics simulations on the characteristics of C, BN, Si, and MoS2 nanotubes in reline has shown that a variety of nanofluids based on reline may be created for various nanotechnology applications. DESshave been discovered to have potential uses in the production of metal hydroxides and oxides [323]. The process involves the release of ammonia from the breakdown of urea, which may react with metal precursors to create intermediates that can then be further processed to create various metal oxides and metal hydroxides. Fe2O3 nanospindles with an average size of around 180 nm were created using an ionothermal method in reline. These Nano spindles showed excellent capacity, long cycle consistency, and significant rate potential when employed as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. In a study the creation of nanoflower-like α-Ni(OH)2 (Fig. 16d, e) in reline with a little quantity of water, which when utilized as an electrodedemonstrated appealing specific capacitances was reported [324]. A DES technique may also be used to generate 2D Co(OH)2, which demonstrated improved pseudocapacitive performance in alkaline aqueous conditions [325]. DESs have been explored for their unique properties in the exfoliation of 2D nanomaterials. Studies have shown that 2D crystals including graphite, boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides may be mechanically exfoliated using a ChCl/urea combination [326,327]. Additionally, it was discovered that stable MoS2 nanosheet dispersions could be made using natural sugars as a green intercalating solvent. The suitability of using DESs as a material for producing 2D nanosheets through ultrasonic exfoliation can be attributed to their favorable combination of low vapor pressure and optimal surface tension which results in a high yield of intact crystalline structures [328]. Although the use of DESs for exfoliating 2D materials is still in its infancy,however, these eco-friendly and inexpensive solvents have the potential to significantly reduce the usage of hazardous organic solvents in the production of few-layered 2D nanomaterials [329]. In order to increase the long-term chemical stability of Ti3C2T x in water, DESs have also been investigated for their prospective usage as antioxidant dispersion media and surface passivation materials. In a recent study, a new approach was proposed to create O-doped FeF3 porous bricks as a conversion-type fluoride cathode for use in lithium batteries. The method utilizes a Fe-based DES composed of nitrite and methylsulfonylmethane as both the reaction medium and precursor, which is cost-effective, safe, and eco-friendly for non-fluorinated metal cations. The cathode network generated by this method effectively reduces volume extrusion and electrode coarsening, leading to high reversible capacity in a wide temperature range (486 and 235 mA h g−1 at 25 °C and –20 °C, respectively), outstanding rate performance (312 mA h g−1 at 1000 mAg−1), and a high energy density of 672.1 W h kg−1 under a power density of 2154.3 W kg−1. Moreover, the fluoride pouch-cell's successful operation with a capacity exceeding 450 mA h g−1, even under lean electrolyte conditions and thin Li foil, indicates the potential for commercial application. These findings suggest that this method could enable the scalable and facile synthesis of conversion-type fluoride cathodes, which could revolutionize the development of high-performance lithium batteries [331]. In nanotechnology, it is possible to carry out investigations using customized DESs that are tailored to the specific application needed, rather than relying solely on well-known and established DESs. These customized DESs can be designed using available materials to ensure optimal performance for the intended task. 7.8 Recycling of electrode materials DESs have been established as effective tools for extracting valuable components from waste LIBs. As manufacturing increases to meet the growing demand for rechargeable LIBs, a significant amount of garbage will be generated [53]. By implementing efficient recycling strategies for LIBs, it is possible to reconcile the needs for raw materials in the battery supply chain with the consequences of discarded LIB waste [332,333]. For example, Co and Li can comprise up to 15% and 7% of the weight of LIB cathodes, respectively. By recycling these metallic elements from discarded LIBs, the risk of material shortages is reduced, as well as the negative impacts of LIB waste on the environment and human health. Metal can be extracted from active lithium metal oxides through various methods, including hydrometallurgy and pyrometallurgy. For large-scale applications, pyrometallurgy is a straightforward and feasible option, but it is limited by the high energy costs associated with the extremely high temperatures required and the production of harmful gases. Hydrometallurgy, due to its high rate of metal leaching and the purity of the recovered product, is one of the most practical processes [334]. Another study demonstrates a closed-loop and highly efficient approach to recycle lithium cobalt oxide from spent LIBs using a ChCl:OA type deep eutectic solvent. The process involves an ultrafast leaching process at 180 °C for 10 s, with no observable residues, and reversible tuning of cobalt ion solubility by adding/evaporating deionized water. This avoids the addition of precipitants and enables easy recovery of the leaching solvent, allowing for a closed-loop recycling process that is both high efficiency and environmentally friendly [335]. DESs are a family of chemicals that have the capacity to dissolve metal oxides efficiently. Therefore, it is rational to recover important components from wasted LIBs using DESs, which give appropriate reducing and dissolving power for the necessary elements. Furthermore, the low-cost and environmentally beneficial features of DESs make them appropriate for scaling applications. Researchers present a method for extracting cobalt by mixing EG with ChCl. Cathode waste from the battery is separated from its components and placed into a DES, where it is heated and agitated. The utilization of precious materials is made possible by the recovery of additional components such as the current collector, binder, and residual conductive carbon by filtration. Cobalt compounds are then recovered using precipitation or electrodeposition. The temperature has a significant impact on the cobalt extraction efficiency, which was attained at 220 °C for 24 h at a rate of 94.1%. At lower temperatures, the reaction time has a minimal influence on the leaching efficiency. At a higher working temperature of 105 °C, the dissolved cobalt content more than quadrupled from 24 to 48 h. The extraction of lithium and cobalt from the NMC cathode was also confirmed using a reline combination under benign circumstances (180 °C) and a brief (12-h) reaction period. Using H2C2O4 and NaOH precipitants, the cobalt may be recycled as Co3O4 by a dilution-precipitation-calcination process [149]. A ChCl:citric acid combination was shown to be an effective agent for extracting cobalt from lithium cobalt oxide in addition to the previously reported DESs. The cobalt extraction rate of this combination was 99.6% under the same circumstances. The scientists also found that over 98% of the cobalt could be recovered by adjusting the leaching conditions, employing a 2:1 molar ratio of ChCl to citric acid, and diluting it with 35% water [336]. Recently, researchers combined ChCl and oxalic acid (OA) to improve the leaching process utilizing microwave-assisted therapy. After just 15 min of microwave heating at 75 °C, this method produced leaching efficiencies of 99% for lithium ions and 96% for manganese ions [337]. Recentlyresearch presented a simple and universal method for choosing organic acids as effective reductants in DESs [53]. Organic acids having a lower ionization potential (IP) were shown to be more reducible than their more powerful counterparts. It was demonstrated that utilizing a combination of hydrous ChCl and L-ascorbic acid as a DES was successful in extracting metals from LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 cathodes during multiple cycles, with remarkable results of over 96% extraction efficiency for Li, Mn, Co, and Ni under moderate conditions. It was discovered that the IP calculation is a useful method for predicting reaction processes and screening reductive acids. Sequential precipitation efficiently recovered the metals, making the DES reusable for several applications and adaptable to processing different kinds of old battery cathodes, all while decreasing secondary chemical waste and pollution [338]. Utilizing DESs to retrieve precious metals from LIBs waste is deemed both eco-friendly and financially viable. DESs offers a sustainable option for recycling and recovering crucial metals from LIBs, as opposed to traditional methods. Nevertheless, for extensive utilization, the incorporation of other reducing agents alongside DESs should be evaluated. For instance, mixing DESs with ecologically acceptable reductants/additives should be investigated in order to decrease the thickness and improve the separation process. Currently, only a small number of DESs have been employed to recover metal from used batteries, but there is enormous potential to broaden the different salts and HBDs used, increasing the number of uses for these solvents. Consequently, it is essential to create DESs that have been thoughtfully crafted, and it is crucial to examine the characteristics used to select appropriate DESs. Furthermore, variables such as processing temperature, pH levels, and reaction duration should be further improved to attain the most favorable economic outcomes. 7.9 Electrocatalytic applications Due to its critical role in the creation of renewable energy sources, electrolysis has made considerable strides in the last decade. Numerous electrocatalytic processes have received a great deal of attention, including the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [339], nitrogen electroreduction reaction (NRR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). DESs have developed into a flexible platform for producing high-performance electrocatalysts with particular structures and morphologies due to their multifunctional functions as solvents, soft templates, and structure-directing agents. Wet-chemical reactions and electrodeposition are two frequently utilized processes for producing electrocatalysts in DES systems. DESs function as ionically conductive mediums with high metal salt solubility during electrodeposition. In contrast, DESs function as safe solvents in wet chemical processes and can also serve as reactants or precursors. Herein, the recent advancements in high-performance electrocatalysts synthesized using DESs for various electrocatalytic reactions have been analyzed. Recently, a group of researchers report the production of stable MoS2 nanosheets in a naturally occurring DES with a sugar basis, serving as intercalating solvents for MoS2 exfoliation. High-resolution TEM images show that the MoS2 was in a mixed phase (2H-1 T) and the electrochemical tests demonstrate that the produced 2H-1 T MoS2 nanosheets exhibit an overpotential of 0.339 V and long-term durability in acidic conditions, with a high yield of roughly 44% compared to other top-down exfoliation methods [340]. Recently in a study, it was shown that the structure and composition of DES may influence how multi-metal oxalate forms and spreads. Oxalic acid is released gradually when high molecular PEG is used, which encourages the growth of a 2D structure. Conversely, low molecular EG and a high quantity of oxalic acid result in the production of 3D nanoparticles. Multiple types of analysis were used to confirm the properties of the resulting multi-metal oxalates, which included the discovery of a single Ni-oxalate phase, a progression in morphology from particles to nanosheets, and a complex composition containing up to five metal elements, including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn. Notably, the skillfully created 2D (FeCoNiCuZn)(C2O4).2H2O nanosheets showed exceptional qualities such as an ultra-low overpotential of 334 mV at 100 mA cm−2 for OER as an electrocatalyst with sustained durability over 30 h at 10 mA cm−2, and a high specific capacity of 1337C g−1 for aqueous supercapacitor use [341]. Methanol/ethanol electrooxidation reaction (MOR/EOR) is a new and efficient method for producing concave cubic PtLa alloy nanocrystals with high-index facets through electrochemical synthesis in DESs. These nanocrystals exhibit exceptional electrocatalytic properties for the oxidation of ethanol [163]. Oxygen electroreduction reaction (ORR), DESs may be easily broken down to produce nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon (NGC), which is then discovered to be an outstanding electrocatalyst for ORR. The results indicate that among the examined samples, the material generated at 900 °C (NGC900) is thought to be the most potent ORR catalyst. With a beginning potential of 0.97 V and a midway potential of 0.84 V, NGC900 specifically exhibits remarkable performance towards ORR and is equivalent to the commercial Pt/C catalyst while having greater stability in alkaline environments [342]. The electrocatalysts employed have a major role in determining the efficiency of these reactions, which is crucial to the performance of sustainable energy devices. It is desired to produce nanocatalysts with high specific surface area (SSA) and high-index facets to increase catalytic activity since the catalytic capabilities of these materials are mostly governed by their surface characteristics. The electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) has been proposed as a promising alternative approach for producing ammonia (NH3) from nitrogen (N2) and water (H2O) in ambient settings using electrocatalysts made with DESs [343]. Despite its exothermic nature, NRR faces challenges such as slow kinetics and complex multi-step procedures due to the difficulty in adsorbing N2 and breaking N≡N bonds. In order to overcome these challenges, researchers are searching for new electrocatalysts that can reduce the energy required for N2 reduction. In this context, Fe3S4 nanosheets produced using a PEG 200/thiourea DES solvothermal technique have been identified as a potential NRR electrocatalyst. The DES not only contributes to the formation of the nanosheet structure but also provides sulphur, a key component in the synthesis of Fe3S4 nanosheets [344]. In another study, DESs were utilized to fabricate catalysts for various electrocatalytic processes, including the creation of high-index faceted Au NCs for glucose electro-oxidation [345].
