Different Au nanostructures were synthesized using reline, and the impact of their surface area and shape on catalytic activity for H2O2 reduction was explored. By adjusting the water concentration in the DES, star-shaped Au nanoparticles with high-index facets were produced, which showed exceptional catalytic activity for H2O2 reduction, with a 150 mV positive shift in starting potential and a 14-fold increase in reduction current density compared to a polycrystalline Au electrode [346]. Additionally, DES-fabricated electrocatalysts were investigated for CO2 reduction, formic acid electrochemical oxidation, urea electrolysis, and hydrazine oxidation [347]. Finally, DESs are very successful in controlling the production of ordered and well-designed nanocatalysts. It is feasible to produce different noble metals with unique architectural patterns and high-index facets using chemical or electrochemical processes because of the amazing degree of designability of these DESs. The production of inexpensive transition metal compounds and heteroatom-doped carbons, both of which exhibit outstanding catalytic activity, has also been accomplished using DESs. However, the intricate chemistry involved in synthesis is still not well understood. Despite this, additional investigation and utilization of DESs' high-performance potential are necessary. More advanced electrocatalysts are highly expected as this field of DESs advances. 7.10 Carbon dioxide capture One of the primary issues associated with the utilization of fossil fuels is the significant levels of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere, thereby presenting a pressing challenge that needs to be addressed. Carbon Dioxide capture is a promising but technically complex approach to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and therefore, global warming [348]. Because of these benefits, ILs have been recommended as a replacement for traditional sorbents in the process of CO2 extraction. This area is subject to the cost and performance of sorbents [349]. Cost-effectiveness analysis shows that DESs are preferable ILs for CO2 collection [350]. This area of study, however, is underexplored and has produced very little research. CO2 collection efficiency is affected by the design and construction of the DES [351-353]. Due to their malleable nature, DESs may be engineered to show promise in terms of their adsorption capability. Different DESs, such as those based on ChCl [354,355], lactate [356], phosphonium, and ammonium [357], have all been investigated as potential CO2 adsorbents [358,359]. According to an analysis, the solubility of CO2 in DES is influenced by the temperature, pressure, and salt/hydrogen bond donor molar ratio (HBD). In general, higher pressure, lower temperature, and lower water content all enhance CO2 solubility [141]. The capacity for CO2 absorption is very sensitive to the kind of salt used and the molar ratio of salt to HBD [350]. Nonetheless, it has been noted that there is a significant discrepancy between the results acquired from various literature sources, calling for rigorous research to ascertain the precise microscopic process. According to molecular dynamic simulations, when CO2 comes into contact with DES, thick layers form, resulting in rapid adsorption of CO2 at the surface. As was previously mentioned, the DES may have its structure and components optimized to increase performance. In this context, the design of a ternary DES aimed toward CO2 collection is illustrative of the work done in this area. Recently, the “synergistic interaction” between the donor and acceptor moieties in a range of new ethylenediamine (EDA)-based DESsresulted in surprisingly high CO2 collection capabilities at higher temperatures [360]. In a study, a task-specific ternary DES containing ChCl, glycerol (Gly), and a superbase (SB)was developed. Specifically, the SB deprotonated the alcohol groups of ChCl and Gly, leading to the formation of alkoxide anions that may reversibly react with CO2 to yield alkyl carbonate salts. In this case, the reaction may even take place at room temperature. Under optimum conditions, a sorbent composed of ChCl, Gly, and DBN (1,5-diazabicyclo[4.3.0]–non-5-ene) in the molar ratio of 1:2:6 could absorb 103 mg CO2 per gramof sorbent [361]. It would only take a little heat in the presence of an inert gas flow to undo the capture reaction. The sorbent proved effective, easy to produce, halogen-free, and stable over several capture/regeneration cycles. According to recent research, it was determined that a combination of DBNH and Oxa in a ratio of 1:0.5, referred to as [DBNH][Oxa]-EG, exhibited the highest level of absorption performance, with a maximum absorption capacity of 0.171 g of CO2 per gram of DES [362]. Recent research used halogen-free solvents to absorb CO2, using 1,2-propanediol and diethylene glycol as HBDs and betaine as HBAs. With a drop in temperature and a rise in pressure, CO2 became more soluble in these solvents, and also with increasing 1,2-propanediol but decreasing diethylene glycol [363]. In another research, it was found that using Ethaline as an electrolytic solution improves the catalytic response in the Au working electrode and is effective in CO2 reduction, with a Faradic efficiency of 81.8%. MD simulations confirm the formation of Ethaline through hydrogen bonding and RDFs show its strong affinity for CO2 absorption (Fig. 17 ) [364]. A study examined CO2 solubility in 5 types of DESs at varying temperatures and pressures, results showed that CO2 uptake improves with decreasing molar ratio of 3-amino-1-propanol. The CO2 capacity of [TBAC]-based DESs was 1:8 > 1:6 > 1:4. Bromide-based DESs had higher CO2 uptake. Results also indicated that CO2 absorption kinetics have multiple stages, varying based on the pure DESs viscosity. The absorption rate drops for 1:4 DES and is dependent on the anion of the composing salt [365]. Recently, a study found that the diffusion coefficients of CO2 in hydrophobic DESs were higher than those in hydrophilic DESs. A correlation was discovered between CO2 diffusivity and viscosity, with the presence of multiple long flexible alkyl chains in the DESs facilitating diffusion. The Wilke-Chang correlations were adjusted to determine the diffusion coefficients of infinite dilution in the examined DESs and could be utilized in future research on CO2 capture utilizing supported liquid membranes or physical absorption methods [366]. These studies, along with others, demonstrate the need for further research into the underlying principles of DESs as potential solutions for capturing gases and other sequestration efforts. Major recent advancements of DESs in electrochemical field are mentioned briefly in Table 1 . 8 Limitations and challenges for DESs in electrochemical applications Due to its promise as a green and sustainable replacement for conventional solvents, DESs are a class of solvents that have attracted a lot of interest recently. DESs are appropriate for usage in a variety of applications because of a number of distinctive characteristics. However, there are several challenges that have hindered the wider adoption of DESs in electrochemical applications [389]. From a broader viewpoint, DES electrolytes should not just be seen as a means of facilitating ion conduction, but as crucial components that contribute to the electrochemical activity, capacity, and rate-limiting performance of batteries. One of the main challenge is the performance of DESs in terms of the narrow electrochemical window against alkali metals. This problem of the narrow electrochemical window is mainly found in HBDs having N–H bonds because of their unstability on the reduction side [390]. To overcome this challenge, new HBDs without active bonds or functional additives for passivating the alkali metal surface should be explored. The physicochemical properties of DES electrolytes also need to be better understood, and ex situ or in situ/operando characterizations along with theoretical simulations should be employed to reveal the influencing mechanism.DESs may also have a high viscosity, and low ionic conductivity, which can make them difficult to handle and use in some applications. These electrolytes may not be suitable for use at room temperature and may perform poorly at low temperatures when compared to advanced liquid organic electrolytes. Additionally, the conductivity required for commercial lithium-ion batteries is 5–15 mS cm−1, which these electrolytes may not meet. To overcome this challenge, novel DES systems with optimized intermolecular interactions need to be developed. This can be achieved by exploring different HBA/HBD pairs with various functionalities and introducing functional additives to weaken the interactions of HBA/HBD. Furthermore, while most literature in this field is focused on Li batteries, more efforts should be dedicated to exploring DES electrolytes based on other metal salts, such as sodium, calcium, and magnesium. DESs also have potential for use in functional nanomaterial synthesis for battery electrodes and catalysts, but the current synthesis processes are inefficient and rely on a trial-and-error strategy, lacking a mechanistic understanding of mass transportation and interfacial behaviors. Several parameters, including viscosity, polarity, surface tension, hydrogen bonding, and coordination with solutes/surfaces, influence species reactivity and mass transport properties and to comprehensively investigate and characterize their impact on the synthesis of DESs for targeted use and to develop the fundamental understanding of DESs, extensive experimental techniques [391] (like NMR, broadband dielectric spectroscopy (BDS), Raman spectroscopy, FTIR, neutron scattering, fluorescence spectroscopy etc.,), computational studies [60,391] (like Simulation and Modeling, Ab Initio Methods, Ab initio molecular dynamics etc.,) [100,236,392–394] and in situ analytical techniques are needed [108]. Additionally, compatibility with electrodes and slow kinetics are ongoing challenges, and many batteries using this electrolyte have insufficient capacity. Despite the potential cost savings and environmental benefits of using DES-based energy storage systems, there is still significant development needed before they can be made available for commercial use. Finally, DESs have shown promise for recycling valuable metals from spent batteries, but there are still several challenges that need to be addressed to make this process more practical and efficient. New DESs with higher capabilities to reduce metal ions and solubility of metal elements are needed, along with simplified post-treatment processes to recover and repurpose the metal ions. The environmental impacts of DESs after being employed should also be assessed, and their recyclability should be established. Despite these challenges, researchers have made significant progress in improving the properties of DESs for use in electrochemical applications. For example, researchers have developed new DES formulations that have a wider electrochemical window, which allows them to be used in a wider range of reactions and measurements. Incorporating a DES into a polymer matrix is a fascinating concept, as it allows for the combination of the unique physicochemical properties of DESs with the robust mechanical properties of polymers, resulting in the development of environmentally friendly materials. Lastly, the concept of designing multiple-component mixtures is particularly intriguing. Although there have been a few reports of ternary and quaternary DESs, they have yet to be fully explored. Introducing water or other cosolvents as a new component has the potential to improve the viscosity, density, conductivity, and electrochemical stability window of DESs, and may even give them flame retardant and antifreeze properties. There is still much that is not known about DESs, and there are many areas where further research is needed. For example, while DESs are generally considered to be less toxic and more biodegradable than traditional solvents, there is still a need for more research on the potential environmental and health impacts of DESs. This includes studies on the biodegradability, toxicity, and persistence of DESs in the environment, as well as their potential to accumulate in living organisms. In addition, there is a need for more data on the performance of DESs in a wider range of applications and under different conditions. In the future, it is possible that DESs will become more widely available and cost-competitive with traditional solvents, and will be used in a variety of applications that rely on electrochemical reactions. As researchers continue to explore the potential of DESs and develop new and innovative uses for them, and as we continue to push for more sustainable and eco-friendly solutions, it's clear that DESs will become a key player in the world of technology. 9 Conclusions Energy storage devices are a vital component of the transition to a cleaner and more sustainable energy system. Energy storage devices also have the potential to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, which can contribute to a healthier environment and a more sustainable future. As solvents play a vital role in the field of energy, the development of new and improved solvents is an important area of research and development. This review has given a comprehensive discussion of deep eutectic solvents as an alternative to the existing solvents in electrochemical energy storage applications. The commercially used organic solvents have some severe drawbacks like toxicity, high cost, and most importantly compromised safety due to their flammable nature. All these drawbacks can be compensated by using aqueous solvents but again the narrow electrochemical window halts their use. So there comes this new cheaper, safer, and greener class of solvents as DESs which has the potential to overcome all the above-mentioned limitations. In this review, we have explored these DESs in detail including their types, significant properties, and their emerging role in the electrochemical energy storage sector. The research in the field of DESs is in its infancy and thus offers the immense possibility of improvement and innovations as these solvents can be designed in numerous ways to meet the requirement of the targeted application. However, there are some limitations of these DESs such as the low conductivity and high viscosity, nonetheless, these properties can be improved by improvising the combination of HBDs and HBAs as well as by exploring additives like water and numerous others. Therefore, to fully realize the potential of DESs as a green and sustainable solvent option there is a crucial need to do further research and development in this field as there are several aspects like the impact of DESs on human health and the environment that still need to be explored extensively. A deep analysis of the molecular interactions through physicochemical studies as well as computationally needs to be done so that new improved and efficient DESs for energy storage applications can be designed. Overall, the future outlook for DESs in energy storage applications is promising, and DESs will likely play an increasingly important role in the development of more sustainable and environmentally friendly advanced energy storage systems and other electrochemical technologies. coredata.dc:description: As the demand for sustainable energy sources continues to rise, the need for efficient and reliable energy storage systems becomes crucial. In order to effectively store and distribute renewable energy, new and innovative solutions must be explored. This review examines the deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as a green, safe, and affordable solution for the electrochemical energy storage and conversion field, offering tremendous opportunities and a promising future. DESs are a class of environment-friendly solvents known for their low toxicity and unique properties, such as their good conductivity, high thermal stability, and non-flammability. This review explores the fundamentals, preparations, and various interactions that often predominate in the formation of DESs, the properties of DESs, and how DESs are better than traditional solvents involving cost-ineffective and unsafe organic electrolytes and ionic liquids as well as inefficient aqueous systems due to low energy density for electrochemical energy storage applications. Then, a particular focus is placed on the various electrochemical applications of DESs, including their role in the electrolytes in batteries/supercapacitors, electropolishing and electrodeposition of metals, synthesis of electrode materials, recycling of electrodes, and their potential for use in CO2 capture. The review concludes by exploring the challenges, research gaps, and future potential of DESs in electrochemical applications, providing a comprehensive overview, and highlighting key considerations for their design and use.
